play.title: Twelfe Night, Or what you will.

scene.stagedir: Enter Orſino Duke of Illyria, Curio, and other Lords.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If Muſicke be the food of Loue, play on,
Giue me exceſſe of it: that ſurfetting,
The appetite may ſicken, and ſo dye.
That ſtraine agen, it had a dying fall:
O, it came ore my eare, like the ſweet ſound
That breathes vpon a banke of Violets;
Stealing, and giuing Odour. Enough, no more,
‘Tis not ſo ſweet now, as it was before.
O ſpirit of Loue, how quicke and freſh art thou,
That notwithſtanding thy capacitie,
Receiueth as the Sea. Nought enters there,
Of what validity, and pitch ſo ere,
But falles into abatement, and low price
Euen in a minute; ſo full of ſhapes is fancie,
That it alone, is high fantaſticall.

speech.speaker: Cu.
speech.line: Will you go hunt my Lord?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What Curio?

speech.speaker: Cu.
speech.line: The Hart.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why ſo I do, the Nobleſt that I haue:
O when mine eyes did ſee Oliuia firſt,
Me thought ſhe purg’d the ayre of peſtilence;
That inſtant was I turn’d into a Hart,
And my deſires like fell and cruell hounds,
Ere ſince purſue me. How now what newes from her?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: So pleaſe my Lord, I might not be admitted,
But from her handmaid do returne this anſwer:
The Element it ſelfe, till ſeuen yeares heate,
Shall not behold her face at ample view:
But like a Cloyſtreſſe ſhe will vailed walke,
And water once a day her Chamber round
With eye-offending brine: all this to ſeaſon
A brothers dead loue, which ſhe would keepe freſh
And laſting, in her ſad remembrance.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O ſhe that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of loue but to a brother,
How will ſhe loue, when the rich golden ſhaft
Hath kill’d the flocke of all affeions elſe
That liue in her. When Liuer, Braine, and Heart,
Theſe ſoueraigne thrones, are all ſupply’d and fill’d
Her ſweete perfeions with one ſelfe king:
Away before me, to ſweet beds of Flowres,
Loue-thoughts lye rich, when canopy’d with bowres.

scene.stagedir: Enter Viola, a Captaine, and Saylors.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: What Country (Friends) is this?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: This is Illyria Ladie.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And what ſhould I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elizium,
Perchance he is not drown’d: What thinke you ſaylors?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: It is perchance that you your ſelfe were ſaued.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: O my poore brother, and ſo perchance may he be.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: True Madam, and to comfort you with chance,
Aſſure your ſelfe, after our ſhip did ſplit,
When you, and thoſe poore number ſaued with you,
Hung on our driuing boate: I ſaw your brother
Moſt prouident in perill, binde himſelfe,
(Courage and hope both teaching him the praiſe)
To a ſtrong Maſte, that liu’d vpon the ſea:
Where like Orion on the Dolphines backe,
I ſaw him hold acquaintance with the waues,
So long as I could ſee.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: For ſaying ſo, there’s Gold:
Mine owne eſcape vnfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy ſpeech ſerues for authoritie
The like of him. Know’ſt thou this Countrey?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: I Madam well, for I was bred and borne
Not three houres trauaile from this very place.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Who gouernes heere?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: A noble Duke in nature, as in name.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: What is his name?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Orſino.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Orſino: I haue heard my father name him.
He was a Batchellor then.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: And ſo is now, or was ſo very late:
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then ‘twas freſh in murmure (as you know
What great ones do, the leſſe will prattle of,)
That he did ſeeke the loue of faire Oliuia.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: What’s ſhee?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: A vertuous maid, the daughter of a Count
That dide ſome tweluemonth ſince, then leauing her
In the proteion of his ſonne, her brother,
Who ſhortly alſo dide: for whoſe deere loue
(They ſay) ſhe hath abiur’d the ſight
And company of men.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: O that I ſeru’d that Lady,
And might not be deliuered to the world
Till I had made mine owne occaſion mellow
What my eſtate is.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: That were hard to compaſſe,
Becauſe ſhe will admit no kinde of ſuite,
No, not the Dukes.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: There is a faire behauiour in thee Captaine,
And though that nature, with a beauteous wall
Doth oft cloſe in pollution: yet of thee
I will beleeue thou haſt a minde that ſuites
With this thy faire and outward charraer.
I prethee (and Ile pay thee bounteouſly)
Conceale me what I am, and be my ayde,
For ſuch diſguiſe as haply ſhall become
The forme of my intent. Ile ſerue this Duke,
Thou ſhalt preſent me as an Eunuch to him,
It may be worth thy paines: for I can ſing,
And ſpeake to him in many ſorts of Muſicke,
That will allow me very worth his ſeruice.
What elſe may hap, to time I will commit,
Onely ſhape thou thy ſilence to my wit.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Be you his Eunuch, and your Mute Ile bee,
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not ſee.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I thanke thee: Lead me on.

speech.speaker: Sir To.
speech.line: What a plague meanes my Neece to take the
death of her brother thus? I am ſure care’s an enemie to
life.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: By my troth ſir Toby, you muſt come in earlyer
a nights: your Coſin, my Lady, takes great exceptions
to your ill houres.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Why let her except, before excepted.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: I, but you muſt confine your ſelfe within the
modeſt limits of order.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Confine? Ile confine my ſelfe no finer then I am:
theſe cloathes are good enough to drinke in, and ſo bee
theſe boots too: and they be not, let them hang them —
ſelues in their owne ſtraps.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: That quaffing and drinking will vndoe you: I
heard my Lady talke of it yeſterday: and of a fooliſh
knight that you brought in one night here, to be hir woer

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Who, Sir Andrew Ague-cheeke?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: I he.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: He’s as tall a man as any’s in Illyria.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: What’s that to th’ purpoſe?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Why he ha’s three thouſand ducates a yeare.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: I, but hee’l haue but a yeare in all theſe ducates:
He’s a very foole, and a prodigall.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Fie, that you’l ſay ſo: he playes o’th Viol-de-gam —
boys, and ſpeaks three or four languages word for word
without booke, & hath all the good gifts of nature.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: He hath indeed, almoſt naturall: for beſides that
he’s a foole, he’s a great quarreller: and but that hee hath
the gift of a Coward, to allay the guſt he hath in quarrel —
ling, ‘tis thought among the prudent, he would quickely
haue the gift of a graue.

speech.speaker: Tob.
speech.line: By this hand they are ſcoundrels and ſubſtra —
ors that ſay ſo of him. Who are they?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: They that adde moreour, hee’s drunke nightly
in your company.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: With drinking healths to my Neece: Ile drinke
to her as long as there is a paſſage in my throat, & drinke
in Illyria: he’s a Coward and a Coyſtrill that will not
drinke to my Neece, till his braines turne o’th toe, like a
pariſh top. What wench? Caſtiliano vulgo: for here coms
Sir Andrew Agueface.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Sir Toby Belch. How now ſir Toby Belch?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Sweet ſir Andrew.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Bleſſe you faire Shrew.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: And you too ſir.

speech.speaker: Tob.
speech.line: Accoſt Sir Andrew, accoſt.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: My Neeces Chamber-maid.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Good Miſtris accoſt, I deſire better acquaintance

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: My name is Mary ſir.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Good miſtris Mary, accoſt.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: You miſtake knight: Accoſt, is front her, boord
her, woe her, aſſayle her.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: By my troth I would not vndertake her in this
company. Is that the meaning of Accoſt?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Far you well Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And thou let part ſo Sir Andrew, would thou
mightſt neuer draw ſword agen.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: And you part ſo miſtris, I would I might neuer
draw ſword agen: Faire Lady, doe you thinke you haue
fooles in hand?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Sir, I haue not you by’th hand.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Marry but you ſhall haue, and heeres my hand.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Now ſir, thought is free: I pray you bring your
hand to’th Buttry barre, and let it drinke.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Wherefore (ſweet-heart?) What’s your Meta —
phor?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: It’s dry ſir.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Why I thinke ſo: I am not ſuch an aſſe, but I
can keepe my hand dry. But what’s your ieſt?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: A dry ieſt Sir.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Are you full of them?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: I Sir, I haue them at my fingers ends: marry now
I let go your hand, I am barren.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: O knight, thou lack’ſt a cup of Canarie: when did
I ſee thee ſo put downe?

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Neuer in your life I thinke, vnleſſe you ſee Ca —
narie put me downe: mee thinkes ſometimes I haue no
more wit then a Chriſtian, or an ordinary man ha’s: but I
am a great eater of beefe, and I beleeue that does harme
to my wit.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: No queſtion.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: And I thought that, I’de forſweare it. Ile ride
home to morrow ſir Toby.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Pur-quoy my deere knight?

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: What is purquoy? Do, or not do? I would I had
beſtowed that time in the tongues, that I haue in fencing
dancing, and beare-bayting: O had I but followed the
Arts.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Then hadſt thou had an excellent head of haire.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Why, would that haue mended my haire?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Paſt question, for thou ſeeſt it will not coole my nature

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: But it becoms me wel enough, doſt not?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Excellent, it hangs like flax on a diſtaffe: & I hope
to ſee a huſwife take thee between her legs, & ſpin it off.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Faith Ile home to morrow ſir Toby, your niece wil
not be ſeene, or if ſhe be it’s four to one, ſhe’l none of me:
the Count himſelfe here hard by, wooes her.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Shee’l none o’th Count, ſhe’l not match aboue hir
degree, neither in eſtate, yeares, nor wit: I haue heard her
ſwear’t. Tut there’s life in’t man.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Ile ſtay a moneth longer. I am a fellow o’th
ſtrangeſt minde i’th world: I delight in Maskes and Re —
uels ſometimes altogether.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Art thou good at theſe kicke-chawſes Knight?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: As any man in Illyria, whatſoeuer he be, vnder
the degree of my betters, & yet I will not compare with
an old man.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Faith, I can cut a caper.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And I can cut the Mutton too’t.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: And I thinke I haue the backe-tricke, ſimply as
ſtrong as any man in Illyria.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Wherefore are theſe things hid? Wherefore haue
theſe gifts a Curtaine before ‘em? Are they like to take
duſt, like miſtris Mals piure? Why doſt thou not goe
to Church in a Galliard, and come home in a Carranto?
My verie walke ſhould be a Iigge: I would not ſo much
as make water but in a Sinke-a-pace: What dooeſt thou
meane? Is it a world to hide vertues in? I did thinke by
the excellent conſtitution of thy legge, it was form’d vn —
der the ſtarre of a Galliard.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: I, ‘tis ſtrong, and it does indifferent well in a
dam’d colour’d ſtocke. Shall we ſit about ſome Reuels?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What ſhall we do elſe: were we not borne vnder
Taurus?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Taurus? That ſides and heart.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: No ſir, it is leggs and thighes: let me ſee thee ca —
per. Ha, higher: ha, ha, excellent.

scene.stagedir: Enter Valentine, and Viola in mans attire.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: If the Duke continue theſe fauours towards you
Ceſario, you are like to be much aduanc’d, he hath known
you but three dayes, and already you are no ſtranger.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: You either feare his humour, or my negligence,
that you call in queſtion the continuance of his loue. Is
he inconſtant ſir, in his fauours. Val. No beleeue me.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I thanke you: heere comes the Count.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Who ſaw Ceſario hoa?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: On your attendance my Lord heere.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Stand you a-while aloofe. Ceſario,
Thou knowſt no leſſe, but all: I haue vnclaſp’d
To thee the booke euen of my ſecret ſoule.
Therefore good youth, addreſſe thy gate vnto her,
Be not deni’de acceſſe, ſtand at her doores,
And tell them, there thy fixed foot ſhall grow
Till thou haue audience.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Sure my Noble Lord,
If ſhe be ſo abandon’d to her ſorrow
As it is ſpoke, ſhe neuer will admit me.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Be clamorous, and leape all ciuill bounds,
Rather then make vnprofited returne.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Say I do ſpeake with her (my Lord) what then?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O then, vnfold the paſsion of my loue,
Surprize her with diſcourſe of my deere faith;
It ſhall become thee well to a my woes:
She will attend it better in thy youth,
Then in a Nuntio’s of more graue aſpe.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I thinke not ſo, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Deere Lad, beleeue it;
For they ſhall yet belye thy happy yeeres,
That ſay thou art a man: Dianas lip
Is not more ſmooth, and rubious: thy ſmall pipe
Is as the maidens organ, ſhrill, and ſound,
And all is ſemblatiue a womans part.
I know thy conſtellation is right apt
For this affayre: ſome foure or fiue attend him,
All if you will: for I my ſelfe am beſt
When leaſt in companie: proſper well in this,
And thou ſhalt liue as freely as thy Lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Ile do my beſt
To woe your Lady: yet a barrefull ſtrife,
Who ere I woe, my ſelfe would be his wife.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Nay, either tell me where thou haſt bin, or I will
not open my lippes ſo wide as a briſsle may enter, in way
of thy excuſe: my Lady will hang thee for thy abſence.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Let her hang me: hee that is well hang’de in this
world, needs to feare no colours.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Make that good.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He ſhall ſee none to feare.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: A good lenton anſwer: I can tell thee where ý
ſaying was borne, of I feare no colours.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Where good miſtris Mary?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: In the warrs, & that may you be bolde to ſay in
your foolerie.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Well, God giue them wiſedome that haue it: &
thoſe that are fooles, let them vſe their talents.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Yet you will be hang’d for being ſo long abſent,
or to be turn’d away: is not that as good as a hanging to
you?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Many a good hanging, preuents a bad marriage:
and for turning away, let ſummer beare it out.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: You are reſolute then?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Not ſo neyther, but I am reſolu’d on two points

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: That if one breake, the other will hold: or if both
breake, your gaskins fall.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Apt in good faith, very apt: well go thy way, if
ſir Toby would leaue drinking, thou wert as witty a piece
of Eues fleſh, as any in Illyria.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Peace you rogue, no more o’that: here comes my
Lady: make your excuſe wisely, you were beſt.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Wit, and’t be thy will, put me into good fooling:
thoſe wits that thinke they haue thee, doe very oft proue
fooles: and I that am ſure I lacke thee, may paſſe for a
wiſe man. For what ſaies Quinapalus, Better a witty foole,
then a fooliſh wit. God bleſſe thee Lady.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Take the foole away.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Do you not heare fellowes, take away the Ladie.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Go too, y’are a dry foole: Ile no more of you: be —
ſides you grow diſ-honeſt.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Two faults Madona, that drinke & good counſell
wil amend: for giue the dry foole drink, then is the foole
not dry: bid the diſhoneſt man mend himſelf, if he mend,
he is no longer diſhoneſt; if hee cannot, let the Botcher
mend him: any thing that’s mended, is but patch’d: vertu
that tranſgreſſes, is but patcht with ſinne, and ſin that a —
mends, is but patcht with vertue. If that this ſimple
Sillogiſme will ſerue, ſo: if it will not, vvhat remedy?
As there is no true Cuckold but calamity, ſo beauties a
flower; The Lady bad take away the foole, therefore I
ſay againe, take her away.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Sir, I bad them take away you.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Miſpriſion in the higheſt degree. Lady, Cucullus
non facit monachum: that’s as much to ſay, as I weare not
motley in my braine: good Madona, giue mee leaue to
proue you a foole.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Can you do it?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Dexteriouſly, good Madona.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Make your proofe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I muſt catechize you for it Madona. Good my
Mouſe of vertue anſwer mee.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Well ſir, for want of other idleneſſe, Ile bide your
proofe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Good Madona, why mournſt thou?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Good foole, for my brothers death.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I thinke his ſoule is in hell, Madona.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I know his ſoule is in heauen, foole.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: The more foole (Madona) to mourne for your
Brothers ſoule, being in heauen. Take away the Foole,
Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What thinke you of this foole Maluolio, doth he
not mend?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Yes, and ſhall do, till the pangs of death ſhake
him: Infirmity that decaies the wiſe, doth euer make the
better foole.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: God ſend you ſir, a ſpeedie Infirmity, for the
better increaſing your folly: Sir Toby will be ſworn that
I am no Fox, but he wil not paſſe his word for two pence
that you are no Foole.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: How ſay you to that Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I maruell your Ladyſhip takes delight in ſuch
a barren raſcall: I ſaw him put down the other day, with
an ordinary foole, that has no more braine then a ſtone.
Looke you now, he’s out of his gard already: vnles you
laugh and miniſter occaſion to him, he is gag’d. I proteſt
I take theſe Wiſemen, that crow ſo at theſe ſet kinde of
fooles, no better then the fooles Zanies.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O you are ſicke of ſelfe-loue Maluolio, and taſte
with a diſtemper’d appetite. To be generous, guitleſſe,
and of free diſpoſition, is to take thoſe things for Bird —
bolts, that you deeme Cannon bullets: There is no ſlan —
der in an allow’d foole, though he do nothing but rayle;
nor no rayling, in a knowne diſscreet man, though hee do
nothing but reproue.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Now Mercury indue thee with leaſing, for thou
ſpeak’ſt well of fooles.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Madam, there is at the gate, a young Gentle —
man, much deſires to ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: From the Count Orſino, is it?

speech.speaker: Ma
speech.line: I know not (Madam) ‘tis a faire young man, and
well attended.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Who of my people hold him in delay?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Sir Toby Madam, your kinſman.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Fetch him off I pray you, he ſpeakes nothing but
madman: Fie on him. Go you Maluolio; If it be a ſuit
from the Count, I am ſicke, or not at home. What you
will, to dismiſſe it.
Now you ſee ſir, how your fooling growes old, & peo —
ple diſlike it.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Thou haſt ſpoke for vs (Madona) as if thy eldeſt
ſonne ſhould be a foole: whoſe ſcull, Ioue cramme with
braines, for heere he comes.
One of thy kin has a moſt weake Pia-mater.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: By mine honor halfe drunke. What is he at the
gate Coſin?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: A Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: A Gentleman? What Gentleman?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: ‘Tis a Gentleman heere. A plague o’theſe pickle
herring: How now Sot.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Good Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Coſin, Coſin, how haue you come ſo earely by
this Lethargie?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Letcherie, I defie Letchery: there’s one at the
gate.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I marry, what is he?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Let him be the diuell and he will, I care not: giue
me faith ſay I. Well, it’s all one.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What’s a drunken man like, foole?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Like a drown’d man, a foole, and a madde man:
One draught aboue heate, makes him a foole, the ſecond
maddes him, and a third drownes him.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Go thou and ſeeke the Crowner, and let him ſitte
o’my Coz: for he’s in the third degree of drinke: hee’s
drown’d: go looke after him.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He is but mad yet Madona, and the foole ſhall
looke to the madman.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Madam, yond young fellow ſweares hee will
ſpeake with you. I told him you were ſicke, he takes on
him to vnderſtand ſo much, and therefore comes to ſpeak
with you. I told him you were aſleepe, he ſeems to haue
a fore knowledge of that too, and therefore comes to
ſpeake with you. What is to be ſaid to him Ladie, hee’s
fortified againſt any deniall.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Tell him, he ſhall not ſpeake with me.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Ha’s beene told ſo: and hee ſayes hee’l ſtand at
your doore like a Sheriffes poſt, and be the ſupporter to
a bench, but hee’l ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What kinde o’man is he?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Why of mankinde.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What manner of man?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Of verie ill manner: hee’l ſpeake with you, will
you, or no.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Of what perſonage, and yeeres is he?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Not yet old enough for a man, nor yong enough
for a boy: as a ſquaſh is before tis a peſcod, or a Codling
when tis almoſt an Apple: Tis with him in ſtanding wa —
ter, betweene boy and man. He is verie well-fauour’d,
and he ſpeakes verie ſhrewiſhly: One would thinke his
mothers milke were ſcarſe out of him.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Let him approach: Call in my Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Gentlewoman, my Lady calles.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Giue me my vaile: come throw it ore my face,
Wee’l once more heare Orſinos Embaſſie.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: The honorable Ladie of the houſe, which is ſhe?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Speake to me, I ſhall anſwer for her: your will.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Moſt radiant, exquiſite, and vnmatchable beau —
tie. I pray you tell me if this bee the Lady of the houſe,
for I neuer ſaw her. I would bee loath to caſt away my
ſpeech: for beſides that it is excellently well pend, I haue
taken great paines to con it. Good Beauties, let mee ſu —
ſtaine no ſcorne; I am very comptible, euen to the leaſt
ſiniſter vſage.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Whence came you ſir?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I can ſay little more then I haue ſtudied, & that
queſtion’s out of my part. Good gentle one, giue mee
modeſt aſſurance, if you be the Ladie of the houſe,
that I may proceede in my ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Are you a Comedian?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: No my profound heart: and yet (by the verie
phangs of malice, I ſweare) I am not that I play. Are you
the Ladie of the houſe?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: If I do not vſurpe my ſelfe, I am.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Moſt certaine, if you are ſhe, you do vſurp your
ſelfe: for what is yours to beſtowe, is, not yours to re —
ſerue. But this is from my Commiſſion: I will on with
my ſpeech in your praiſe, and then ſhew you the heart of
my meſſage.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Come to what is important in’t: I forgiue you
the praiſe.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Alas, I tooke great paines to ſtudie it, and ‘tis
Poeticall.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: It is the more like to be feigned, I pray you keep
it in. I heard you were ſawcy at my gates, & allowd your
approach rather to wonder at you, then to heare you. If
you be not mad, be gone: if you haue reaſon, be breefe:
‘tis not that time of Moone with me, to make one in ſo
skipping a dialogue.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Will you hoyſt ſayle ſir, here lies your way.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: No good ſwabber, I am to hull here a little lon —
ger. Some mollification for your Giant, ſweete Ladie;
tell me your minde, I am a meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Sure you haue ſome hiddeous matter to deliuer,
when the curteſie of it is ſo fearefull. Speake your office.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: It alone concernes your eare: I bring no ouer —
ture of warre, no taxation of homage; I hold the Olyffe
in my hand: my words are as full of peace, as matter.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Yet you began rudely. What are you?
What would you?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: The rudeneſſe that hath appear’d in mee, haue I
learn’d from my entertainment. What I am, and what I
would, are as ſecret as maiden-head: to your eares, Di —
uinity; to any others, prophanation.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Giue vs the place alone,
We will heare this diuinitie. Now ſir, what is your text?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Moſt ſweet Ladie.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: A comfortable dorine, and much may bee ſaide
of it. Where lies your Text?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: In Orſinoes boſome.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: In his boſome? In what chapter of his boſome?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: To anſwer by the method, in the firſt of his hart.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O, I haue read it: it is hereſie. Haue you no more
to ſay?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Good Madam, let me ſee your face.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Haue you any Commiſsion from your Lord, to
negotiate with my face: you are now out of your Text:
but we will draw the Curtain, and ſhew you the piure.
Looke you ſir, ſuch a one I was this preſent: Iſt not well
done?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Excellently done, if God did all.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: ‘Tis in graine ſir, ‘twill endure winde and wea —
ther.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Tis beauty truly blent, whoſe red and white,
Natures owne ſweet, and cunning hand laid on:
Lady, you are the cruell’ſt ſhee aliue,
If you will leade theſe graces to the graue,
And leaue the world no copie.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O ſir, I will not be ſo hard-hearted: I will giue
out diuers ſcedules of my beautie. It ſhalbe Inuentoried
and euery particle and vtenſile labell’d to my will: As,
Item two lippes indifferent redde, Item two grey eyes,
with lids to them: Item, one necke, one chin, & ſo forth.
Were you ſent hither to praiſe me?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I ſee you what you are, you are too proud:
But if you were the diuell, you are faire:
My Lord, and maſter loues you: O ſuch loue
Could be but recompenc’d, though you were crown’d
The non-pareil of beautie.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: How does he loue me?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: With adorations, fertill teares,
With groanes that thunder loue, with ſighes of fire.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Your Lord does know my mind, I cannot loue him
Yet I ſuppoſe him vertuous, know him noble,
Of great eſtate, of freſh and ſtainleſſe youth;
In voyces well divulg’d, free, learn’d, and valiant,
And in dimenſion, and the ſhape of nature,
A gracious perſon; But yet I cannot loue him:
He might haue tooke his anſwer long ago.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: If I did loue you in my maſters flame,
With ſuch a ſuffring, ſuch a deadly life:
In your deniall, I would finde no ſence,
I would not vnderſtand it.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Why, what would you?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Make me a willow Cabine at your gate,
And call vpon my ſoule within the houſe,
Write loyall Cantons of contemned loue,
And ſing them lowd euen in the dead of night:
Hallow your name to the reuerberate hilles,
And make the babling Goſsip of the aire,
Cry out Oliuia: O you ſhould not reſt
Betweene the elements of ayre, and earth,
But you ſhould pittie me.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: You might do much:
What is your Parentage?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Aboue my fortunes, yet my ſtate is well:
I am a Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Get you to your Lord:
I cannot loue him: let him ſend no more,
Vnleſſe (perchance) you come to me againe,
To tell me how he takes it: Fare you well:
I thanke you for your paines: ſpend this for mee.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I am no feede poaſt, Lady; keepe your purſe,
My Maſter, not my ſelfe, lackes recompence.
Loue make his heart of flint, that you ſhal loue,
And let your feruour like my maſters be,
Plac’d in contempt: Farwell fayre crueltie.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What is your Parentage?
Aboue my fortunes, yet my ſtate is well;
I am a Gentleman. Ile be ſworne thou art,
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbes, aions, and ſpirit,
Do giue thee fiue-fold blazon: not too faſt: ſoft, ſoft,
Vnleſſe the Maſter were the man. How now?
Euen ſo quickly may one catch the plague?
Me thinkes I feele this youths perfeions
With an inuiſible, and ſubtle ſtealth
To creepe in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.
What hoa, Maluolio.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Heere Madam, at your ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Run after that ſame peeuiſh Meſſenger
The Countes man: he left this Ring behinde him
Would I, or not: tell him, Ile none of it.
Deſire him not to flatter with his Lord,
Nor hold him vp with hopes, I am not for him:
If that the youth will come this way to morrow,
Ile giue him reasons for’t: hie thee Maluolio.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I do I know not what, and feare to finde
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my minde:
Fate, ſhew thy force, our ſelues we do not owe,
What is decreed, muſt be: and be this ſo.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Will you ſtay no longer: nor will you not that
I go with you.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: By your patience, no: my ſtarres ſhine darkely
ouer me; the malignancie of my fate, might perhaps di —
ſtemper yours; therefore I ſhall craue of you your leaue,
that I may beare my euils alone. It were a bad recom —
pence for your loue, to lay any of them on you.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Let me yet know of you, whither you are bound.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: No ſooth ſir: my determinate voyage is meere
extrauagancie. But I perceiue in you ſo excellent a touch
of modeſtie, that you will not extort from me, what I am
willing to keepe in: therefore it charges me in manners,
the rather to expreſſe my ſelfe: you muſt know of mee
then Antonio, my name is Sebaſtian (which I call’d Rodo-
rigo) my father was that Sebaſtian of Meſſaline, whom I
know you haue heard of. He left behinde him, my ſelfe,
and a ſiſter, both borne in an houre: if the Heauens had
beene pleas’d, would we had ſo ended. But you ſir, al —
ter’d that, for ſome houre before you tooke me from the
breach of the ſea, was my ſiſter drown’d.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Alas the day.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: A Lady ſir, though it was ſaid ſhee much reſem —
bled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but thogh
I could not with ſuch eſtimable wonder ouer-farre be —
leeue that, yet thus farre I will boldly publiſh her, ſhee
bore a minde that enuy could not but call faire: Shee is
drown’d already ſir with ſalt water, though I ſeeme to
drowne her remembrance againe with more.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Pardon me ſir, your bad entertainment.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: O good Antonio, forgiue me your trouble.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: If you will not murther me for my loue, let mee
be your ſeruant.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: If you will not vndo what you haue done, that is
kill him, whom you haue recouer’d, deſire it not. Fare
ye well at once, my boſome is full of kindneſſe, and I
am yet ſo neere the manners of my mother, that vpon the
leaſt occasion more, mine eyes will tell tales of me: I am
bound to the Count Orſino’s Court, farewell.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The gentleneſſe of all the gods go with thee:
I haue many enemies in Orſino’s Court,
Elſe would I very ſhortly ſee thee there:
But come what may, I do adore thee ſo,
That danger ſhall ſeeme ſport, and I will go.

scene.stagedir: Enter Viola and Maluolio, at ſeuerall doores.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Were not you eu’n now, with the Counteſſe O-
liuia?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Euen now ſir, on a moderate pace, I haue ſince a —
riu’d but hither.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: She returnes this Ring to you (ſir) you might
haue ſaued mee my paines, to haue taken it away your
ſelfe. She adds moreouer, that you ſhould put your Lord
into a deſperate aſſurance, ſhe will none of him. And one
thing more, that you be neuer ſo hardie to come againe
in his affaires, vnleſſe it bee to report your Lords taking
of this: receiue it ſo.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: She tooke the Ring of me, Ile none of it.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Come ſir, you peeuiſhly threw it to her: and
her will is, it ſhould be ſo return’d: If it bee worth ſtoo —
ping for, there it lies, in your eye: if not, bee it his that
findes it.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I left no Ring with her: what meanes this Lady?
Fortune forbid my out-ſide haue not charm’d her:
She made good view of me, indeed ſo much,
That me thought her eyes had loſt her tongue,
For ſhe did ſpeake in ſtarts diſtraedly.
She loues me ſure, the cunning of her paſsion
Inuites me in this churliſh meſſenger:
None of my Lords Ring? Why he ſent her none;
I am the man, if it be ſo, as tis,
Poore Lady, ſhe were better loue a dreame:
Diſguiſe, I ſee thou art a wickedneſſe,
Wherein the pregnant enemie does much.
How eaſie is it, for the proper falſe
In womens waxen hearts to ſet their formes:
Alas, O frailtie is the cauſe, not wee,
For ſuch as we are made, if ſuch we bee:
How will this fadge? My maſter loues her deerely,
And I (poore monſter) fond aſmuch on him:
And ſhe (mistaken) ſeemes to dote on me:
What will become of this? As I am man,
My ſtate is deſperate for my maiſters loue:
As I am woman (now alas the day)
What thriftleſſe ſighes ſhall poore Oliuia breath?
O time, thou muſt vntangle this, not I,
It is too hard a knot for me t’ vnty.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Toby, and Sir Andrew.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Approach Sir Andrew: not to bee a bedde after
midnight, is to be vp betimes, and Deliculo ſurgere, thou
know’ſt.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Nay by my troth I know not: but I know, to
be vp late, is to be vp late.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: A falſe concluſion: I hate it as an vnfill’d Canne.
To be vp after midnight, and to go to bed then is early:
ſo that to go to bed after midnight, is to goe to bed be —
times. Does not our liues conſiſt of the foure Ele —
ments?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Faith ſo they ſay, but I thinke it rather conſiſts
of eating and drinking.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Th’art a ſcholler; let vs therefore eate and drinke
Marian I ſay, a ſtoope of wine.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Heere comes the foole yfaith.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: How now my harts: Did you neuer ſee the Pic —
ture of we three?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Welcome aſſe, now let’s haue a catch.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: By my troth the foole has an excellent breaſt. I
had rather then forty ſhillings I had ſuch a legge, and ſo
ſweet a breath to ſing, as the foole has. Inſooth thou waſt
in very gracious fooling laſt night, when thou ſpok’ſt of
Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians paſsing the Equinoial of
Queubus: ‘twas very good yfaith: I ſent thee ſixe pence
for thy Lemon, hadſt it?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I did impeticos thy gratillity: for Maluolios noſe
is no Whip-ſtocke. My Lady has a white hand, and the
Mermidons are no bottle-ale houſes.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Excellent: Why this is the beſt fooling, when
all is done. Now a ſong.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come on, there is ſixe pence for you. Let’s haue
a ſong.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: There’s a teſtrill of me too: if one knight giue a

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Would you haue a loue-ſong, or a ſong of good
life?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: A loue ſong, a loue ſong.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I, I. I care not for good life.
O Miſtris mine where are you roming?
O ſtay and heare, your true loues coming,
That can ſing both high and low.
Trip no further prettie ſweeting.
Iourneys end in louers meeting,
Euery wiſe mans ſonne doth know.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Excellent good, ifaith.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Good, good.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What is loue, tis not heereafter,
Preſent mirth, hath preſent laughter:
What’s to come, is ſtill vnſure.
In delay there lies no plentie,
Then come kiſſe me ſweet and twentie:
Youths a ſtuffe will not endure.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: A mellifluous voyce, as I am true knight.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: A contagious breath.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Very ſweet, and contagious ifaith.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: To heare by the noſe, it is dulcet in contagion.
But ſhall we make the Welkin dance indeed? Shall wee
rowze the night-Owle in a Catch, that will drawe three
ſoules out of one Weauer? Shall we do that?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: And you loue me, let’s doo’t: I am dogge at a
Catch.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Byrlady ſir, and ſome dogs will catch well.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Moſt certaine: Let our Catch be, Thou Knaue.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Hold thy peace, thou Knaue knight. I ſhall be con —
ſtrain’d in’t, to call thee knaue, Knight.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: ‘Tis not the firſt time I haue conſtrained one to
call me knaue. Begin foole: it begins, Hold thy peace.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I ſhall neuer begin if I hold my peace.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Good ifaith: Come begin.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What a catterwalling doe you keepe heere? If
my Ladie haue not call’d vp her Steward Maluolio, and
bid him turne you out of doores, neuer truſt me.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: My Lady’s a Catayan, we are politicians, Maluolios
a Peg-a-ramſie, and Three merry men be wee. Am not I
conſanguinious? Am I not of her blood: tilly vally. La —
die, There dwelt a man in Babylon, Lady, Lady.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Beſhrew me, the knights in admirable fooling.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I, he do’s well enough if he be diſpos’d, and ſo
do I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it more
naturall.

line.emph: O the twelfe day of December.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: For the loue o’ God peace.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: My maſters are you mad? Or what are you?
Haue you no wit, manners, nor honeſtie, but to gabble
like Tinkers at this time of night? Do yee make an Ale —
houſe of my Ladies houſe, that ye ſqueak out your Cozi —
ers Catches without any mitigation or remorſe of voice?
Is there no reſpe of place, perſons, nor time in you?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: We did keepe time ſir in our Catches. Snecke vp.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir Toby, I muſt be round with you. My Lady
bad me tell you, that though ſhe harbors you as her kinſ —
man, ſhe’s nothing ally’d to your diſorders. If you can
ſeparate your ſelfe and your miſdemeanors, you are wel —
come to the houſe: if not, and it would pleaſe you to take
leaue of her, ſhe is very willing to bid you farewell.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Farewell deere heart, ſince I muſt needs be gone.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nay good Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: His eyes do ſhew his dayes are almoſt done.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Is’t euen ſo?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: But I will neuer dye.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir Toby there you lye.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: This is much credit to you.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Shall I bid him go.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What and if you do?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Shall I bid him go, and ſpare not?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: O no, no, no, no, you dare not.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Out o’ tune ſir, ye lye: Art any more then a Stew —
ard? Doſt thou thinke becauſe thou art vertuous, there
ſhall be no more Cakes and Ale?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Yes by S. Anne, and Ginger ſhall bee hotte y’th
mouth too.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Th’art i’th right. Goe ſir, rub your Chaine with
crums. A ſtope of Wine Maria.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Miſtris Mary, if you priz’d my Ladies fauour
at any thing more then contempt, you would not giue
meanes for this vnciuill rule; ſhe ſhall know of it by this
hand.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Go ſhake your eares.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: ‘Twere as good a deede as to drink when a mans
a hungrie, to challenge him the field, and then to breake
promiſe with him, and make a foole of him.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Doo’t knight, Ile write thee a Challenge: or Ile
deliuer thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sweet Sir Toby be patient for to night: Since
the youth of the Counts was to day with my Lady, ſhe is
much out of quiet. For Monſieur Maluolio, let me alone
with him: If I do not gull him into an ayword, and make
him a common recreation, do not thinke I haue witte e —
nough to lye ſtraight in my bed: I know I can do it.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Poſſeſſe vs, poſſeſſe vs, tell vs ſomething of him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Marrie ſir, ſometimes he is a kinde of Puritane.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: O, if I thought that, Ide beate him like a dogge.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What for being a Puritan, thy exquiſite reaſon,
deere knight.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I haue no exquiſite reaſon for’t, but I haue reaſon
good enough.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The diu’ll a Puritane that hee is, or any thing
conſtantly but a time-pleaſer, an affeion’d Aſſe, that
cons State without booke, and vtters it by great ſwarths.
The beſt perſwaded of himſelfe: ſo cram’d (as he thinkes)
with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith, that all
that looke on him, loue him: and on that vice in him, will
my reuenge finde notable cauſe to worke.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What wilt thou do?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I will drop in his way ſome obſcure Epiſtles of
loue, wherein by the colour of his beard, the ſhape of his
legge, the manner of his gate, the expreſſure of his eye,
forehead, and compleion, he ſhall finde himſelfe moſt
feelingly perſonated. I can write very like my Ladie
your Neece, on a forgotten matter wee can hardly make
distinion of our hands.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Excellent, I ſmell a deuice.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I hau’t in my noſe too.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: He ſhall thinke by the Letters that thou wilt drop
that they come from my Neece, and that ſhee’s in loue
with him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My purpoſe is indeed a horſe of that colour.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: And your horſe now would make him an Aſſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Aſſe, I doubt not.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: O twill be admirable.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sport royall I warrant you: I know my Phy —
ſicke will worke with him, I will plant you two, and let
the Foole make a third, where he ſhall finde the Letter:
obſerue his conſtruion of it: For this night to bed, and
dreame on the euent: Farewell.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Good night Penthiſilea.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Before me ſhe’s a good wench.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: She’s a beagle true bred, and one that adores me:
what o’that?

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I was ador’d once too.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Let’s to bed knight: Thou hadſt neede ſend for
more money.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: If I cannot recouer your Neece, I am a foule way
out.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Send for money knight, if thou haſt her not i’th
end, call me Cut.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: If I do not, neuer truſt me, take it how you will.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come, come, Ile go burne ſome Sacke, tis too late
to go to bed now: Come knight, come knight.

scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and others.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Giue me ſome Muſick; Now good morow frends.
Now good Ceſario, but that peece of ſong,
That old and Anticke ſong we heard laſt night;
Me thought it did releeue my paſſion much,
More then light ayres, and recolleed termes
Of theſe moſt briske and giddy-paced times.
Come, but one verſe.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: He is not heere (ſo pleaſe your Lordſhippe) that
ſhould ſing it?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Who was it?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Feſte the Ieſter my Lord, a foole that the Ladie
Oliuiaes Father tooke much delight in. He is about the
houſe.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Seeke him out, and play the tune the while.
Come hither Boy, if euer thou ſhalt loue
In the ſweet pangs of it, remember me:
For ſuch as I am, all true Louers are,
Vnſtaid and skittiſh in all motions elſe,
Saue in the conſtant image of the creature
That is belou’d. How doſt thou like this tune?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: It giues a verie eccho to the ſeate
Where loue is thron’d.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Thou doſt ſpeake maſterly,
My life vpon’t, yong though thou art, thine eye
Hath ſtaid vpon ſome fauour that it loues:
Hath it not boy?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: A little, by your fauour.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What kinde of woman iſt?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Of your compleion.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: She is not worth thee then. What yeares ifaith?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: About your yeeres my Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Too old by heauen: Let ſtill the woman take
An elder then her ſelfe, ſo weares ſhe to him;
So ſwayes ſhe leuell in her husbands heart:
For boy, howeuer we do praiſe our ſelues,
Our fancies are more giddie and vnfirme,
More longing, wauering, ſooner loſt and worne,
Then womens are.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I thinke it well my Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Then let thy Loue be yonger then thy ſelfe,
Or thy affeion cannot hold the bent:
For women are as Roſes, whoſe faire flowre
Being once diſplaid, doth fall that verie howre.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And ſo they are: alas, that they are ſo:
To die, euen when they to perfeion grow.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O fellow come, the ſong we had laſt night:
Marke it Ceſario, it is old and plaine;
The Spinſters and the Knitters in the Sun,
And the free maides that weaue their thred with bones,
Do vſe to chaunt it: it is ſilly ſooth,
And dallies with the innocence of loue,
Like the old age.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Are you ready Sir?

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: I prethee ſing.

stanza.line: Come away, come away death,
And in ſad cypreſſe let me be laide.
Fye away, fie away breath,
I am ſlaine by a faire cruell maide:
My ſhrowd of white, ſtuck all with Ew, O prepare it.
My part of death no one ſo true did ſhare it.
Not a flower, not a flower ſweete
On my blacke coffin, let there be ſtrewne:
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poore corpes, where my bones ſhall be throwne:
A thouſand thouſand ſighes to ſaue, lay me ô where
Sad true louer neuer find my graue, to weepe there.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: There’s for thy paines.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No paines ſir, I take pleaſure in ſinging ſir.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Ile pay thy pleaſure then.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Truely ſir, and pleaſure will be paide one time, or
another.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Giue me now leaue, to leaue thee.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Now the melancholly God prote thee, and the
Tailor make thy doublet of changeable Taffata, for thy
minde is a very Opall. I would haue men of ſuch conſtan —
cie put to Sea, that their buſineſſe might be euery thing,
and their intent euerie where, for that’s it, that alwayes
makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Let all the reſt giue place: Once more Ceſario,
Get thee to yond ſame ſoueraigne crueltie:
Tell her my loue, more noble then the world
Prizes not quantitie of dirtie lands,
The parts that fortune hath beſtow’d vpon her:
Tell her I hold as giddily as Fortune:
But ‘tis that miracle, and Queene of Iems
That nature prankes her in, attras my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: But if ſhe cannot loue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: It cannot be ſo anſwer’d.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Sooth but you muſt.
Say that ſome Lady, as perhappes there is,
Hath for your loue as great a pang of heart
As you haue for Oliuia: you cannot loue her:
You tel her ſo: Muſt ſhe not then be anſwer’d?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: There is no womans ſides
Can bide the beating of ſo ſtrong a paſſion,
As loue doth giue my heart: no womans heart
So bigge, to hold ſo much, they lacke retention.
Alas, their loue may be call’d appetite,
No motion of the Liuer, but the Pallat,
That ſuffer ſurfet, cloyment, and reuolt,
But mine is all as hungry as the Sea,
And can digeſt as much, make no compare
Betweene that loue a woman can beare me,
And that I owe Oliuia.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I but I know.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What doſt thou knowe?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Too well what loue women to men may owe:
In faith they are as true of heart, as we.
My Father had a daughter lou’d a man
As it might be perhaps, were I a woman
I ſhould your Lordship.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: And what’s her hiſtory?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: A blanke my Lord: ſhe neuer told her loue,
But let concealment like a worme i’th budde
Feede on her damaske cheeke: ſhe pin’d in thought,
And with a greene and yellow melancholly,
She ſate like Patience on a Monument,
Smiling at greefe. Was not this loue indeede?
We men may ſay more, ſweare more, but indeed
Our ſhewes are more then will: for ſtill we proue
Much in our vowes, but little in our loue.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: But di’de thy ſiſter of her loue my Boy?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I am all the daughters of my Fathers houſe,
And all the brothers too: and yet I know not.
Sir, ſhall I to this Lady?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: I that’s the Theame,
To her in haſte: giue her this Iewell: ſay,
My loue can giue no place, bide no denay.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come thy wayes Signior Fabian.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Nay Ile come: if I looſe a ſcruple of this ſport,
let me be boyl’d to death with Melancholly.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Wouldſt thou not be glad to haue the niggard —
ly Raſcally ſheepe-biter, come by ſome notable ſhame?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: I would exult man: you know he brought me out
o’ fauour with my Lady, about a Beare-baiting heere.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: To anger him wee’l haue the Beare againe, and
we will foole him blacke and blew, ſhall we not ſir An-
drew?

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: And we do not, it is pittie of our liues.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Heere comes the little villaine: How now my
Mettle of India?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Get ye all three into the box tree: Maluolio’s
comming downe this walke, he has beene yonder i’the
Sunne praiſing behauiour to his own ſhadow this halfe
houre: obſerue him for the loue of Mockerie: for I know
this Letter wil make a contemplatiue Ideot of him. Cloſe
in the name of ieaſting, lye thou there: for heere comes
the Trowt, that muſt be caught with tickling.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: ‘Tis but Fortune, all is fortune. Maria once
told me ſhe did affe me, and I haue heard her ſelf come
thus neere, that ſhould ſhee fancie, it ſhould bee one of
my compleion. Beſides ſhe vſes me with a more ex —
alted respe, then any one elſe that followes her. What
ſhould I thinke on’t?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Heere’s an ouer-weening rogue.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Oh peace: Contemplation makes a rare Turkey
Cocke of him, how he iets vnder his aduanc’d plumes.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Slight I could ſo beate the Rogue.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Peace I ſay.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: To be Count Maluolio.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Ah Rogue.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Piſtoll him, piſtoll him.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Peace, peace.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: There is example for’t: The Lady of the Stra-
chy, married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Fie on him Iezabel.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: O peace, now he’s deepely in: looke how imagi —
nation blowes him.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Hauing beene three moneths married to her,
ſitting in my ſtate.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: O for a ſtone-bow to hit him in the eye.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Calling my Officers about me, in my branch’d
Veluet gowne: hauing come from a day bedde, where I
haue left Oliuia ſleeping.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Fire and Brimſtone.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: O peace, peace.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: And then to haue the humor of ſtate: and after
a demure trauaile of regard: telling them I knowe my
place, as I would they ſhould doe theirs: to aske for my
kinſman Toby.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Boltes and ſhackles.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Oh peace, peace, peace, now, now.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Seauen of my people with an obedient ſtart,
make out for him: I frowne the while, and perchance
winde vp my watch, or play with my ſome rich Iewell:
Toby approaches; curtſies there to me.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Shall this fellow liue?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Though our ſilence be drawne from vs with cars,
yet peace.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I extend my hand to him thus: quenching my
familiar ſmile with an auſtere regard of controll.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And do’s not Toby take you a blow o’the lippes,
then?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Saying, Coſine Toby, my Fortunes hauing caſt
me on your Neece, giue me this prerogatiue of ſpeech.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What, what?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: You muſt amend your drunkenneſſe.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Out ſcab.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Nay patience, or we breake the ſinewes of our
plot?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Beſides you waſte the treaſure of your time,
with a fooliſh knight.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: That’s mee I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: One ſir Andrew.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: I knew ‘twas I, for many do call mee foole.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: What employment haue we heere?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Now is the Woodcocke neere the gin.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Oh peace, and the ſpirit of humors intimate rea —
ding aloud to him.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: By my life this is my Ladies hand: theſe bee her
very C’s, her V’s, and her T’s, and thus makes ſhee her
great P’s. It is in contempt of queſtion her hand.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Her C’s, her V’s, and her T’s: why that?

speech.speaker: Mal.

line.emph: To the vnknowne belou’d, this, and my good Wiſhes:

speech.line: Her very Phrases: By your leaue wax. Soft, and the im —
preſſure her Lucrece, with which ſhe vſes to ſeale: tis my
Lady: To whom ſhould this be?

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: This winnes him, Liuer and all.

speech.speaker: Mal.

line.emph: Ioue knowes I loue, but who, Lips do not mooue, no

speech.line: man muſt know. No man muſt know. What followes?
The numbers alter’d: No man muſt know,
If this ſhould be thee Maluolio?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Marrie hang thee brocke.

line.emph: I may command where I adore, but ſilence like a Lu-
creſſe knife:
With bloodleſſe ſtroke my heart doth gore, M.O.A.I. doth
ſway my life.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: A fuſtian riddle.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Excellent Wench, ſay I.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: M.O.A.I. doth ſway my life. Nay but firſt
let me ſee, let me ſee, let me ſee.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: What diſh a poyſon has ſhe dreſt him?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And with what wing the ſtallion checkes at it?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I may command, where I adore: Why ſhee may
command me: I ſerue her, ſhe is my Ladie. Why this is
euident to any formall capacitie. There is no obſtruion
in this, and the end: What ſhould that Alphabeticall po —
ſition portend, if I could make that reſemble ſomething
in me? Softly, M.O.A.I.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: O I, make vp that, he is now at a cold ſent.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Sowter will cry vpon’t for all this, though it bee
as ranke as a Fox.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: M. Maluolio, M. why that begins my name.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Did not I ſay he would worke it out, the Curre
is excellent at faults.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: M. But then there is no conſonancy in the ſequell
that ſuffers vnder probation: A. ſhould follow, but O.
does.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: And O ſhall end, I hope.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I, or Ile cudgell him, and make him cry O.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: And then I. comes behind.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: I, and you had any eye behinde you, you might
ſee more detraion at your heeles, then Fortunes before
you.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: M,O,A,I. This ſimulation is not as the former:
and yet to cruſh this a little, it would bow to mee, for e —
uery one of theſe Letters are in my name. Soft, here fol —
lowes proſe: If this fall into thy hand, reuolue. In my ſtars
I am aboue thee, but be not affraid of greatneſſe: Some
are become great, ſome atcheeues greatneſſe, and ſome
haue greatneſſe thruſt vppon em. Thy fates open theyr
hands, let thy blood and ſpirit embrace them, and to in —
vre thy ſelfe to what thou art like to be: caſt thy humble
ſlough, and appeare freſh. Be oppoſite with a kinſman,
ſurly with ſeruants: Let thy tongue tang arguments of
ſtate; put thy ſelfe into the tricke of ſingularitie. Shee
thus aduiſes thee, that ſighes for thee. Remember who
commended thy yellow ſtockings, and wiſh’d to ſee thee
euer croſſe garter’d: I ſay remember, goe too, thou art
made if thou deſir’ſt to be ſo: If not, let me ſee thee a ſte —
ward ſtill, the fellow of ſeruants, and not woorthie to
touch Fortunes fingers Farewell, Shee that would alter
ſeruices with thee, the fortunate vnhappy daylight and
champian diſcouers not more: This is open, I will bee
proud, I will reade pollticke Authours, I will baffle Sir
Toby, I will waſh off groſſe acquaintance, I will be point
deuiſe, the very man. I do not now foole my ſelfe, to let
imagination iade mee; for euery reaſon excites to this,
that my Lady loues me. She did commend my yellow
ſtockings of late, ſhee did praiſe my legge being croſſe —
garter’d, and in this ſhe manifeſts her ſelfe to my loue, &
with a kinde of iniunion driues mee to theſe habites of
her liking. I thanke my ſtarres, I am happy: I will bee
ſtrange, ſtout, in yellow ſtockings, and croſſe Garter’d,
euen with the ſwiftneſſe of putting on. Ioue, and my
ſtarres be praiſed. Heere is yet a poſtſcript. Thou canſt

line.emph: not chooſe but know who I am. If thou entertainſt my loue, let
it appeare in thy ſmiling, thy ſmiles become thee well. There-
fore in my preſence ſtill ſmile, deero my ſweete, I prethee. Ioue

speech.line: I thanke thee, I will ſmile, I wil do euery thing that thou wilt haue me.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: I will not giue my part of this ſport for a penſi —
on of thouſands to be paid from the Sophy.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I could marry this wench for this deuice.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: So could I too.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And aske no other dowry with her, but ſuch ano —
ther ieſt.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Nor I neither.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Heere comes my noble gull catcher.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Wilt thou ſet thy foote o’my necke.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Or o’mine either?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Shall I play my freedome at tray-trip, and becom
thy bondſlaue?

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Ifaith, or I either?

speech.speaker: Tob.
speech.line: Why, thou haſt put him in ſuch a dreame, that
when the image of it leaues him, he muſt run mad.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Nay but ſay true, do’s it worke vpon him?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Like Aqua vite with a Midwife.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If you will then ſee the fruites of the ſport, mark
his firſt approach before my Lady: hee will come to her
in yellow ſtockings, and ‘tis a colour ſhe abhorres, and
croſſe garter’d, a faſhion ſhee deteſts: and hee will ſmile
vpon her, which will now be ſo vnſuteable to her diſpo —
ſition, being addied to a melancholly, as ſhee is, that it
cannot but turn him into a notable contempt: if you wil
ſee it follow me.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: To the gates of Tartar, thou moſt excellent diuell
of wit.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Ile make one too.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Saue thee Friend and thy Muſick: doſt thou liue
by thy Tabor?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No ſir, I liue by the Church.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Art thou a Churchman?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No ſuch matter ſir, I do liue by the Church: For,
I do liue at my houſe, and my houſe dooth ſtand by the
Church

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: So thou maiſt ſay the Kings lyes by a begger, if a
begger dwell neer him: or the Church ſtands by thy Ta —
bor, if thy Tabor ſtand by the Church.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: You haue ſaid ſir: To ſee this age: A ſentence is
but a cheu’rill gloue to a good witte, how quickely the
wrong ſide may be turn’d outward.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Nay that’s certaine: they that dally nicely with
words, may quickely make them wanton.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I would therefore my ſiſter had had no name Sir.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Why man?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why ſir, her names a word, and to dallie with
that word, might make my ſiſter wanton: But indeede,
words are very Raſcals, ſince bonds diſgrac’d them.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Thy reaſon man?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Troth ſir, I can yeeld you none without wordes,
and wordes are growne ſo falſe, I am loath to proue rea —
ſon with them.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I warrant thou art a merry fellow, and car’ſt for
nothing.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Not ſo ſir, I do care for ſomething: but in my con —
ſcience ſir, I do not care for you: if that be to care for no —
thing ſir, I would it would make you inuiſible.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Art not thou the Lady Oliuia’s foole?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No indeed ſir, the Lady Oliuia has no folly, ſhee
will keepe no foole ſir, till ſhe be married, and fooles are
as like husbands, as Pilchers are to Herrings, the Huſ —
bands the bigger, I am indeede not her foole, but hir cor —
rupter of words.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I ſaw thee late at the Count Orſino’s.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Foolery ſir, does walke about the Orbe like the
Sun, it ſhines euery where. I would be ſorry ſir, but the
Foole ſhould be as oft with your Maſter, as with my Mi —
ſtris: I thinke I ſaw your wiſedome there.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Nay, and thou paſſe vpon me, Ile no more with
thee. Hold there’s expences for thee.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Now Ioue in his next commodity of hayre, ſend
thee a beard.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: By my troth Ile tell thee, I am almoſt ſicke for
one, though I would not haue it grow on my chinne. Is
thy Lady within?

speech.speaker: Clo
speech.line: Would not a paire of theſe haue bred ſir?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Yes being kept together, and put to vſe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia ſir, to bring
a Creſſida to this Troylus.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I vnderſtand you ſir, tis well begg’d.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: The matter I hope is not great ſir; begging, but a
begger: Creſſida was a begger. My Lady is within ſir. I
will conſter to them whence you come, who you are, and
what you would are out of my welkin, I might ſay Ele —
ment, but the word is ouer-worne.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: This fellow is wiſe enough to play the foole,
And to do that well, craues a kinde of wit:
He muſt obſerue their mood on whom he ieſts,
The quality of perſons, and the time:
And like the Haggard, checke at euery Feather
That comes before his eye. This is a praice,
As full of labour as a Wiſe-mans Art:
For folly that he wiſely ſhewes, is fit;
But wiſemens folly falne, quite taint their wit.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Saue you Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And you ſir.

line.emph: Dieu vou guard Mónſieur.
Et vouz ouſie voſtre ſeruiture.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I hope ſir, you are, and I am yours.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Will you incounter the houſe, my Neece is deſi —
rous you ſhould enter, if your trade be to her.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I am bound to your Neece ſir, I meane ſhe is the
liſt of my voyage.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Taſte your legges ſir, put them to motion.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My legges do better vnderſtand me ſir, then I vn —
derſtand what you meane by bidding me taſte my legs.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I meane to go ſir, to enter.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I will anſwer you with gate and entrance, but we
are preuented.
Moſt excellent accompliſh’d Lady, the heauens raine O —
dours on you.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: That youth’s a rare Courtier, raine odours, wel.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My matter hath no voice Lady, but to your owne
moſt pregnant and vouchſafed eare.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Odours, pregnant, and vouchſafed: Ile get ‘em
all three already.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Let the Garden doore be ſhut, and leaue mee to
my hearing. Giue me your hand ſir.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My dutie Madam, and moſt humble ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What is your name?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Ceſario is your ſeruants name, faire Princeſſe.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: My ſeruant ſir? ‘Twas neuer merry world,
Since lowly feigning was call’d complement:
y’are ſeruant to the Count Orſino youth.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And he is yours, and his muſt needs be yours:
Your ſeruants ſeruant, is your ſeruant Madam.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: For him, I thinke not on him: for his thoughts,
Would they were blankes, rather then fill’d with me.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalfe.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O by your leaue I pray you.
I bad you neuer ſpeake againe of him;
But would you vndertake another ſuite
I had rather heare you, to ſolicit that,
Then Muſicke from the ſpheares.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Deere Lady.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Giue me leaue, beſeech you: I did ſend,
After the laſt enchantment you did heare,
A Ring in chace of you. So did I abuſe
My ſelfe, my ſeruant, and I feare me you:
Vnder your hard conſtruion muſt I ſit,
To force that on you in a ſhamefull cunning
Which you knew none of yours. What might you think?
Haue you not ſet mine Honor at the ſtake,
And baited it with all th’ vnmuzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiuing
Enough is ſhewne, a Cipreſſe, not a boſome,
Hides my heart: ſo let me heare you ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I pittie you.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: That’s a degree to loue.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: No not a grize: for tis a vulgar proofe
That verie oft we pitty enemies.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Why then me thinkes ‘tis time to ſmile agen:
O world, how apt the poore are to be proud?
If one ſhould be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the Lion, then the Wolfe?
The clocke vpbraides me with the waſte of time:
Be not affraid good youth, I will not haue you,
And yet when wit and youth is come to harueſt,
Your wife is like to reape a proper man:
There lies your way, due Weſt.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Then Weſtward hoe:
Grace and good diſpoſition attend your Ladyſhip:
You’l nothing Madam to my Lord, by me:

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Stay: I prethee tell me what thou thinkſt of me?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: That you do thinke you are not what you are.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: If I thinke ſo, I thinke the ſame of you.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Then thinke you right: I am not what I am.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I would you were, as I would haue you be.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Would it be better Madam, then I am?
I wiſh it might, for now I am your foole.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O what a deale of ſcorne, lookes beautifull?
In the contempt and anger of his lip,
A murdrous guilt ſhewes not it ſelfe more ſoone,
Then loue that would ſeeme hid: Loues night, is noone.
Ceſario, by the Roſes of the Spring,
By maid-hood, honor, truth, and euery thing,
I loue thee ſo, that maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit, nor reaſon, can my paſſion hide:
Do not extort thy reaſons from this clauſe,
For that I woo, thou therefore haſt no cauſe:
But rather reaſon thus, with reaſon fetter;
Loue ſought, is good: but giuen vnſought, is better.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: By innocence I ſweare, and by my youth,
I haue one heart, one boſome, and one truth,
And that no woman has, nor neuer none
Shall miſtris be of it, ſaue I alone.
And ſo adieu good Madam, neuer more,
Will I my Maſters teares to you deplore.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Yet come againe: for thou perhaps mayſt moue
That heart which now abhorres, to like his loue.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: No faith, Ile not ſtay a iot longer:

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Thy reaſon deere venom, giue thy reaſon.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: You muſt needes yeelde your reaſon, Sir An-
drew?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Marry I ſaw your Neece do more fauours to the
Counts Seruing-man, then euer ſhe bestow’d vpon mee:
I ſaw’t i’th Orchard.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Did ſhe ſee the while, old boy, tell me that.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: As plaine as I ſee you now.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: This was a great argument of loue in her toward
you.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: S’light; will you make an Aſſe o’me.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: I will proue it legitimate ſir, vpon the Oathes of
iudgement, and reaſon.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And they haue beene grand Iurie men, ſince before
Noah was a Saylor.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Shee did ſhew fauour to the youth in your ſight,
onely to exaſperate you, to awake your dormouſe valour,
to put fire in your Heart, and brimſtone in your Liuer:
you ſhould then haue accoſted her, and with ſome excel —
lent ieſts, fire-new from the mint, you ſhould haue bangd
the youth into dumbeneſſe: this was look’d for at your
hand, and this was baulkt: the double gilt of this oppor —
tunitie you let time waſh off, and you are now ſayld into
the North of my Ladies opinion, where you will hang
like an yſickle on a Dutchmans beard, vnleſſe you do re —
deeme it, by ſome laudable attempt, either of valour or
policie.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: And’t be any way, it muſt be with Valour, for
policie I hate: I had as liefe be a Browniſt, as a Politi —
cian.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Why then build me thy fortunes vpon the baſis of
valour. Challenge me the Counts youth to fight with him
hurt him in eleuen places, my Neece ſhall take note of it,
and aſſure thy ſelfe, there is no loue-Broker in the world,
can more preuaile in mans commendation with woman,
then report of valour.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: There is no way but this ſir Andrew.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Will either of you beare me a challenge to him?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Go, write it in a martial hand, be curſt and briefe:
it is no matter how wittie, ſo it bee eloquent, and full of
inuention: taunt him with the licenſe of Inke: if thou
thou’ſt him ſome thrice, it ſhall not be amiſſe, and as ma —
ny Lyes, as will lye in thy ſheete of paper, although the
ſheete were bigge enough for the bedde of Ware in Eng —
land, ſet ‘em downe, go about it. Let there bee gaulle e —
nough in thy inke, though thou write with a Gooſe-pen,
no matter: about it.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Where ſhall I finde you?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Wee’l call thee at the Cubiculo: Go.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: This is a deere Manakin to you Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I haue beene deere to him lad, ſome two thouſand
ſtrong, or ſo.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: We ſhall haue a rare Letter from him; but you’le
not deliuer’t.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Neuer truſt me then: and by all meanes ſtirre on
the youth to an anſwer. I thinke Oxen and waine-ropes
cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were open’d
and you finde ſo much blood in his Liuer, as will clog the
foote of a flea, Ile eate the reſt of th’ anatomy.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: And his oppoſit the youth beares in his viſage no
great preſage of cruelty.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Looke where the youngeſt Wren of mine comes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If you deſire the ſpleene, and will laughe your
ſelues into ſtitches, follow me; yond gull Maluolio is tur —
ned Heathen, a verie Renegatho; for there is no chriſtian
that meanes to be ſaued by beleeuing rightly, can euer
beleeue ſuch impoſſible paſſages of groſſeneſſe. Hee’s in
yellow ſtockings.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: And croſſe garter’d?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Moſt villanouſly: like a Pedant that keepes a
Schoole i’th Church: I haue dogg’d him like his murthe —
rer. He does obey euery point of the Letter that I dropt,
to betray him: He does ſmile his face into more lynes,
then is in the new Mappe, with the augmentation of the
Indies: you haue not ſeene ſuch a thing as tis: I can hard —
ly forbeare hurling things at him, I know my Ladie will
ſtrike him: if ſhee doe, hee’l ſmile, and take’t for a great
fauour.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come bring vs, bring vs where he is.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I would not by my will haue troubled you,
But ſince you make your pleaſure of your paines,
I will no further chide you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I could not ſtay behinde you: my deſire
(More ſharpe then filed ſteele) did ſpurre me forth,
And not all loue to ſee you (though ſo much
As might haue drawne one to a longer voyage)
But iealouſie, what might befall your trauell,
Being ſkilleſſe in theſe parts: which to a ſtranger,
Vnguided, and vnfriended, often proue
Rough, and vnhoſpitable. My willing loue,
The rather by theſe arguments of feare
Set forth in your purſuite.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: My kinde Anthonio,
I can no other anſwer make, but thankes,
And thankes: and euer oft good turnes,
Are ſhuffel’d off with ſuch vncurrant pay:
But were my worth, as is my conſcience firme,
You ſhould finde better dealing: what’s to do?
Shall we go ſee the reliques of this Towne?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To morrow ſir, beſt firſt go ſee your Lodging?

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I am not weary, and ‘tis long to night
I pray you let vs ſatisfie our eyes
With the memorials, and the things of fame
That do renowne this City.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Would youl’d pardon me:
I do not without danger walke theſe ſtreetes.
Once in a ſea-fight ‘gainſt the Count his gallies,
I did ſome ſeruice, of ſuch note indeede,
That were I tane heere, it would ſcarſe be anſwer’d.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Belike you ſlew great number of his people.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Th’ offence is not of ſuch a bloody nature,
Albeit the quality of the time, and quarrell
Might well haue giuen vs bloody argument:
It might haue ſince bene anſwer’d in repaying
What we tooke from them, which for Traffiques ſake
Moſt of our City did. Onely my ſelfe ſtood out,
For which if I be lapſed in this place
I ſhall pay deere.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Do not then walke too open.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: It doth not fit me: hold ſir, here’s my purſe,
In the South Suburbes at the Elephant
Is beſt to lodge: I will beſpeake our dyet,
Whiles you beguile the time, and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the Towne, there ſhall you haue me.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Why I your purſe?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Haply your eye ſhall light vpon ſome toy
You haue deſire to purchaſe: and your ſtore
I thinke is not for idle Markets, ſir.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Ile be your purſe-bearer, and leaue you
For an houre.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To th’ Elephant.

speech.speaker: Seb
speech.line: I do remember.
