speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I haue ſent after him, he ſayes hee’l come:
How ſhall I feaſt him? What beſtow of him?
For youth is bought more oft, then begg’d, or borrow’d.
I ſpeake too loud: Where’s Maluolio, he is ſad, and ciuill,
And ſuites well for a ſeruant with my fortunes,
Where is Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: He’s comming Madame:
But in very ſtrange manner. He is ſure poſſeſt Madam.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Why what’s the matter, does he raue?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No Madam, he does nothing but ſmile: your La —
dyſhip were beſt to haue ſome guard about you, if hee
come, for ſure the man is tainted in’s wits.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Go call him hither.
I am as madde as hee,
If ſad and merry madneſſe equall bee.
How now Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sweet Lady, ho, ho.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Smil’ſt thou? I ſent for thee vpon a ſad occaſion.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sad Lady, I could be ſad:
This does make ſome obſtruion in the blood:
This croſſe-gartering, but what of that?
If it pleaſe the eye of one, it is with me as the very true
Sonnet is: Pleaſe one, and pleaſe all.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Why how doeſt thou man?
What is the matter with thee?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Not blacke in my minde, though yellow in my
legges: It did come to his hands, and Commaunds ſhall
be executed. I thinke we doe know the ſweet Romane
hand.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Wilt thou go to bed Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: To bed? I ſweet heart, and Ile come to thee.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: God comfort thee: Why doſt thou ſmile ſo, and
kiſſe thy hand ſo oft?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: How do you Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Maluo.
speech.line: At your requeſt:
Yes Nightingales anſwere Dawes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why appeare you with this ridiculous bold —
neſſe before my Lady.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Be not afraid of greatneſſe: ‘twas well writ.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What meanſt thou by that Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Some are borne great.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Some atcheeue greatneſſe.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What ſayſt thou?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: And ſome haue greatneſſe thruſt vpon them.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Heauen reſtore thee.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Remember who commended thy yellow ſtock —
ings.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Thy yellow ſtockings?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: And wiſh’d to ſee thee croſſe garter’d.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Croſſe garter’d?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Go too, thou art made, if thou deſir’ſt to be ſo.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Am I made?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: If not, let me ſee thee a ſeruant ſtill.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Why this is verie Midſommer madneſſe.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Madame, the young Gentleman of the Count
Orſino’s is return’d, I could hardly entreate him backe: he
attends your Ladyſhips pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Ile come to him.
Good Maria, let this fellow be lookd too. Where’s my
Coſine Toby, let ſome of my people haue a ſpeciall care
of him, I would not haue him miſcarrie for the halfe of
my Dowry.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Oh ho, do you come neere me now: no worſe
man then ſir Toby to looke to me. This concurres dire —
ly with the Letter, ſhe ſends him on purpoſe, that I may
appeare ſtubborne to him: for ſhe incites me to that in
the Letter. Caſt thy humble ſlough ſayes ſhe: be oppo —
ſite with a Kinſman, ſurly with ſeruants, let thy tongue
langer with arguments of ſtate, put thy ſelfe into the
tricke of ſingularity: and conſequently ſetts downe the
manner how: as a ſad face, a reuerend carriage, a ſlow
tongue, in the habite of ſome Sir of note, and ſo foorth.
I haue lymde her, but it is Ioues doing, and Ioue make me
thankefull. And when ſhe went away now, let this Fel —
low be look’d too: Fellow? not Maluolio, nor after my
degree, but Fellow. Why euery thing adheres togither,
that no dramme of a ſcruple, no ſcruple of a ſcruple, no
obſtacle, no incredulous or vnſafe circumſtance: What
can be ſaide? Nothing that can be, can come betweene
me, and the full proſpe of my hopes. Well Ioue, not I,
is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Which way is hee in the name of ſanity. If all
the diuels of hell be drawne in little, and Legion himſelfe
poſſeſt him, yet Ile ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Heere he is, heere he is: how iſt with you ſir?
How iſt with you man?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Go off, I diſcard you: let me enioy my priuate:
go off.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Lo, how hollow the fiend ſpeakes within him;
did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my Lady prayes you to haue
a care of him.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Ah ha, does ſhe ſo?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Go too, go too: peace, peace, wee muſt deale
gently with him: Let me alone. How do you Maluolio?
How iſt with you? What man, defie the diuell: conſider,
he’s an enemy to mankinde.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Do you know what you ſay?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: La you, and you ſpeake ill of the diuell, how
he takes it at heart. Pray God he be not bewitch’d.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Carry his water to th’ wiſe woman.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Marry and it ſhall be done to morrow morning
if I liue. My Lady would not looſe him for more then ile
ſay.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: How now miſtris?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh Lord.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Prethee hold thy peace, this is not the way: Doe
you not ſee you moue him? Let me alone with him.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: No way but gentleneſſe, gently, gently: the Fiend
is rough, and will not be roughly vs’d.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Why how now my bawcock? how doſt ӳ chuck?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I biddy, come with me. What man, tis not for
grauity to play at cherrie-pit with ſathan Hang him foul
Colliar.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Get him to ſay his prayers, good ſir Toby gette
him to pray.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: My prayers Minx.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No I warrant you, he will not heare of godly —
neſſe.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Go hang your ſelues all: you are ydle ſhallowe
things, I am not of your element, you ſhall knowe more
heereafter.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Iſt poſsible?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: If this were plaid vpon a ſtage now, I could con —
demne it as an improbable fiion.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: His very genius hath taken the infeion of the
deuice man.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nay purſue him now, leaſt the deuice take ayre,
and taint.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Why we ſhall make him mad indeede.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The houſe will be the quieter.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come, wee’l haue him in a darke room & bound.
My Neece is already in the beleefe that he’s mad: we may
carry it thus for our pleaſure, and his pennance, til our ve —
ry paſtime tyred out of breath, prompt vs to haue mercy
on him: at which time, we wil bring the deuice to the bar
and crowne thee for a finder of madmen: but ſee, but ſee.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: More matter for a May morning.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Heere’s the Challenge, reade it: I warrant there’s
vinegar and pepper in’t.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Iſt ſo ſawcy?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: I, iſt? I warrant him: do but read.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Giue me.

line.emph: Youth, whatſoeuer thou art, thou art but a ſcuruy fellow.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Good, and valiant.

speech.speaker: To.

line.emph: Wonder not, nor admire not in thy minde why I doe call

speech.line: thee ſo, for I will ſhew thee no reaſon for’t.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: A good note, that keepes you from the blow of ý Law

line.emph: Thou comſt to the Lady Oliuia, and in my ſight ſhe vſes
thee kindly: but thou lyeſt in thy throat, that is not the matter
I challenge thee for.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Very breefe, and to exceeding good ſence-leſſe.

line.emph: I will way-lay thee going home, where if it be thy chance
to kill me.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Good.

line.emph: Thou kilſt me like a rogue and a villaine.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Still you keepe o’th windie ſide of the Law: good.

speech.speaker: Tob.

line.emph: Fartheewell, and God haue mercie vpon one of our
ſoules. He may haue mercie vpon mine, but my hope is better,
and ſo looke to thy ſelfe. Thy friend as thou vſeſt him, & thy

speech.line: ſworne enemie, Andrew Ague-cheeke.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: If this Letter moue him not, his legges cannot:
Ile giu’t him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You may haue verie fit occaſion for’t: he is now
in ſome commerce with my Ladie, and will by and by
depart.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Go ſir Andrew: ſcout mee for him at the corner
of the Orchard like a bum-Baylie: ſo ſoone as euer thou
ſeeſt him, draw, and as thou draw’ſt, ſweare horrible: for
it comes to paſſe oft, that a terrible oath, with a ſwagge —
ring accent ſharpely twang’d off, giues manhoode more
approbation, then euer proofe it ſelfe would haue earn’d
him. Away.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Nay let me alone for ſwearing.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Now will not I deliuer his Letter: for the behaui —
our of the yong Gentleman, giues him out to be of good
capacity, and breeding: his employment betweene his
Lord and my Neece, confirmes no leſſe. Therefore, this
Letter being ſo excellently ignorant, will breed no terror
in the youth: he will finde it comes from a Clodde-pole.
But ſir, I will deliuer his Challenge by word of mouth;
ſet vpon Ague-cheeke a notable report of valor, and driue
the Gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receiue it)
into a moſt hideous opinion of his rage, skill, furie, and
impetuoſitie. This will ſo fright them both, that they wil
kill one another by the looke, like Cockatrices.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Heere he comes with your Neece, giue them way
till he take leaue, and preſently after him.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I wil meditate the while vpon ſome horrid meſſage
for a Challenge.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I haue ſaid too much vnto a hart of ſtone,
And laid mine honour too vnchary on’t:
There’s ſomething in me that reproues my fault:
But ſuch a head-ſtrong potent fault it is,
That it but mockes reproofe.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: With the ſame hauiour that your paſſion beares,
Goes on my Maſters greefes.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Heere, weare this Iewell for me, tis my piure:
Refuſe it not, it hath no tongue, to vex you:
And I beſeech you come againe to morrow.
What ſhall you aske of me that Ile deny,
That honour (ſau’d) may vpon asking giue.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Nothing but this, your true loue for my maſter.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: How with mine honor may I giue him that,
Which I haue giuen to you.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I will acquit you.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Well, come againe to morrow: far-thee-well,
A Fiend like thee might beare my ſoule to hell.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Gentleman, God ſaue thee.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And you ſir.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: That defence thou haſt, betake the too’t: of what
nature the wrongs are thou haſt done him, I knowe not:
but thy intercepter full of deſpight, bloody as the Hun —
ter, attends thee at the Orchard end: diſmount thy tucke,
be yare in thy preparation, for thy aſſaylant is quick, ſkil —
full, and deadly.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: You miſtake ſir I am ſure, no man hath any quar —
rell to me: my remembrance is very free and cleere from
any image of offence done to any man.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: You’l finde it otherwiſe I aſſure you: therefore, if
you hold your life at any price, betake you to your gard:
for your oppoſite hath in him what youth, ſtrength, ſkill,
and wrath, can furniſh man withall.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I pray you ſir what is he?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: He is knight dubb’d with vnhatch’d Rapier, and
on carpet conſideration, but he is a diuell in priuate brall,
ſoules and bodies hath he diuorc’d three, and his incenſe —
ment at this moment is ſo implacable, that ſatisfaion
can be none, but by pangs of death and ſepulcher: Hob,
nob, is his word: giu’t or take’t.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I will returne againe into the houſe, and deſire
ſome condu of the Lady. I am no fighter, I haue heard
of ſome kinde of men, that put quarrells purpoſely on o —
thers, to taſte their valour: belike this is a man of that
quirke.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Sir, no: his indignation deriues it ſelfe out of a ve —
ry computent iniurie, therefore get you on, and giue him
his deſire. Backe you ſhall not to the houſe, vnleſſe you
vndertake that with me, which with as much ſafetie you
might anſwer him: therefore on, or ſtrippe your ſword
ſtarke naked: for meddle you muſt that’s certain, or for —
ſweare to weare iron about you.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: This is as vnciuill as ſtrange. I beſeech you doe
me this courteous office, as to know of the Knight what
my offence to him is: it is ſomething of my negligence,
nothing of my purpoſe.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I will doe ſo. Signiour Fabian, ſtay you by this
Gentleman, till my returne.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Pray you ſir, do you know of this matter?

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: I know the knight is incenſt againſt you, euen to
a mortall arbitrement, but nothing of the circumſtance
more.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I beſeech you what manner of man is he?

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Nothing of that wonderfull promiſe to read him
by his forme, as you are like to finde him in the proofe of
his valour. He is indeede ſir, the moſt ſkilfull, bloudy, &
fatall oppoſite that you could poſsibly haue found in anie
part of Illyria: will you walke towards him, I will make
your peace with him, if I can.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I ſhall bee much bound to you for’t: I am one,
that had rather go with ſir Prieſt, then ſir knight: I care
not who knowes ſo much of my mettle.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Why man hee s a verie diuell, I haue not ſeen ſuch
a firago: I had a paſſe with him, rapier, ſcabberd, and all:
and he giues me the ſtucke in with ſuch a mortall motion
that it is ineuitable: and on the anſwer, he payes you as
ſurely, as your feete hits the ground they ſtep on. They
ſay, he has bin Fencer to the Sophy.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Pox on’t, Ile not meddle with him.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I but he will not now be pacified,
Fabian can ſcarſe hold him yonder.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Plague on’t, and I thought he had beene valiant,
and ſo cunning in Fence, I’de haue ſeene him damn’d ere
I’de haue challeng’d him. Let him let the matter ſlip, and
Ile giue him my horſe, gray Capilet.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Ile make the motion: ſtand heere, make a good
ſhew on’t, this ſhall end without the perdition of ſoules,
marry Ile ride your horſe as well as I ride you.
I haue his horſe to take vp the quarrell, I haue perſwaded
him the youths a diuell.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: He is as horribly conceited of him: and pants, &
lookes pale, as if a Beare were at his heeles.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: There’s no remedie ſir, he will fight with you for’s
oath ſake: marrie hee hath better bethought him of his
quarrell, and hee findes that now ſcarſe to bee worth tal —
king of: therefore draw for the ſupportance of his vowe,
he proteſts he will not hurt you.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Pray God defend me: a little thing would make
me tell them how much I lacke of a man.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Giue ground if you ſee him furious.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come ſir Andrew, there’s no remedie, the Gen —
tleman will for his honors ſake haue one bowt with you:
he cannot by the Duello auoide it: but hee has promiſed
me, as he is a Gentleman and a Soldiour, he will not hurt
you. Come on, too’t.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Pray God he keepe his oath.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I do aſſure you tis againſt my will.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Put vp your ſword: if this yong Gentleman
Haue done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defie you.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: You ſir? Why, what are you?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: One ſir, that for his loue dares yet do more
Then you haue heard him brag to you he will.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Nay, if you be an vndertaker, I am for you.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: O good ſir Toby hold: heere come the Officers.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Ile be with you anon.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Pray ſir, put your ſword vp if you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Marry will I ſir: and for that I promis’d you Ile
be as good as my word. Hee will beare you eaſily, and
raines well.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: This is the man, do thy Office.

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: Anthonio, I arreſt thee at the ſuit of Count Orſino

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: You do miſtake me ſir.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: No ſir, no iot: I know your fauour well:
Though now you haue no ſea-cap on your head:
Take him away, he knowes I know him well.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I muſt obey. This comes with ſeeking you:
But there’s no remedie, I ſhall anſwer it:
What will you do: now my neceſſitie
Makes me to aske you for my purſe. It greeues mee
Much more, for what I cannot do for you,
Then what befals my ſelfe: you ſtand amaz’d,
But be of comfort.

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: Come ſir away.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I muſt entreat of you ſome of that money.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: What money ſir?
For the fayre kindneſſe you haue ſhew’d me heere,
And part being prompted by your preſent trouble,
Out of my leane and low ability
Ile lend you ſomething: my hauing is not much,
Ile make diuiſion of my preſent with you:
Hold, there’s halfe my Coffer.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Will you deny me now,
Iſt poſſible that my deſerts to you
Can lacke perſwaſion. Do not tempt my miſery,
Leaſt that it make me ſo vnſound a man
As to vpbraid you with thoſe kindneſſes
That I haue done for you.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: I know of none,
Nor know I you by voyce, or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man,
Then lying, vainneſſe, babling drunkenneſſe,
Or any taint of vice, whoſe ſtrong corruption
Inhabites our fraile blood.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oh heauens themſelues.

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: Come ſir, I pray you go.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let me ſpeake a little. This youth that you ſee heere,
I ſnatch’d one halfe out of the iawes of death,
Releeu’d him with ſuch ſanitie of loue;
And to his image, which me thought did promiſe
Moſt venerable worth, did I deuotion.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: What’s that to vs, the time goes by: Away.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: But oh, how vilde an idoll proues this God:
Thou haſt Sebaſtian done good feature, ſhame.
In Nature, there’s no blemiſh but the minde:
None can be call’d deform’d, but the vnkinde.
Vertue is beauty, but the beauteous euill
Are empty trunkes, ore-flouriſh’d by the deuill.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: The man growes mad, away with him:
Come, come ſir.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Leade me on.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Me thinkes his words do from ſuch paſsion flye
That he beleeues himſelfe, ſo do not I:
Proue true imagination, oh proue true,
That I deere brother, be now tane for you.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come hither Knight, come hither Fabian: Weel
whiſper ore a couplet or two of moſt ſage ſawes.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: He nam’d Sebaſtian: I my brother know
Yet liuing in my glaſſe: euen ſuch, and ſo
In fauour was my Brother, and he went
Still in this faſhion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: Oh if it proue,
Tempeſts are kinde, and ſalt waues freſh in loue.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: A very diſhoneſt paltry boy, and more a coward
then a Hare, his diſhoneſty appeares, in leauing his frend
heere in neceſſity, and denying him: and for his coward —
ſhip aske Fabian.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: A Coward, a moſt deuout Coward, religious in
it.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Slid Ile after him againe, and beate him.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Do, cuffe him ſoundly, but neuer draw thy ſword

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: And I do not.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Come, let’s ſee the euent.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: I dare lay any money, twill be nothing yet.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Will you make me beleeue, that I am not ſent for
you?

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Go too, go too, thou art a fooliſh fellow,
Let me be cleere of thee.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Well held out yfaith: No, I do not know you,
nor I am not ſent to you by my Lady, to bid you come
ſpeake with her: nor your name is not Maſter Ceſario,
nor this is not my noſe neyther: Nothing that is ſo, is ſo.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I prethee vent thy folly ſome-where elſe, thou
know’ſt not me.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Vent my folly: He has heard that word of ſome
great man, and now applyes it to a foole. Vent my fol —
ly: I am affraid this great lubber the World will proue a
Cockney: I prethee now vngird thy ſtrangenes, and tell
me what I ſhall vent to my Lady? Shall I vent to hir that
thou art comming?

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I prethee fooliſh greeke depart from me, there’s
money for thee, if you tarry longer, I ſhall giue worſe
paiment.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: By my troth thou haſt an open hand: theſe Wiſe —
men that giue fooles money, get themſelues a good re —
port, after foureteene yeares purchaſe.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Now ſir, haue I met you again: ther’s for you.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Why there’s for thee, and there, and there,
Are all the people mad?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Hold ſir, or Ile throw your dagger ore the houſe

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: This will I tell my Lady ſtraight, I would not be
in ſome of your coats for two pence.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come on ſir, hold.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Nay let him alone, Ile go another way to worke
with him: Ile haue an aion of Battery againſt him, if
there be any law in Illyria: though I ſtroke him firſt, yet
it’s no matter for that.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Let go thy hand.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Come ſir, I will not let you go. Come my yong
ſouldier put vp your yron: you are well fleſh’d: Come
on.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I will be free from thee. What wouldſt ӳ now?
If thou dar’ſt tempt me further, draw thy ſword.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: What, what? Nay then I muſt haue an Ounce or
two of this malapert blood from you.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Hold Toby, on thy life I charge thee hold.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Will it be euer thus? Vngracious wretch,
Fit for the Mountaines, and the barbarous Caues,
Where manners nere were preach’d: out of my ſight.
Be not offended, deere Ceſario:
Rudesbey be gone. I prethee gentle friend,
Let thy fayre wiſedome, not thy paſsion ſway
In this vnciuill, and vniuſt extent
Againſt thy peace. Go with me to my houſe,
And heare thou there how many fruitleſſe prankes
This Ruffian hath botch’d vp, that thou thereby
Mayſt ſmile at this: Thou ſhalt not chooſe but goe:
Do not denie, beſhrew his ſoule for mee,
He ſtarted one poore heart of mine, in thee.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: What relliſh is in this? How runs the ſtreame?
Or I am mad, or elſe this is a dreame:
Let fancie ſtill my ſenſe in Lethe ſteepe,
If it be thus to dreame, ſtill let me ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Nay come I prethee, would thoud’ſt be rul’d by me

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O ſay ſo, and ſo be.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nay, I prethee put on this gown, & this beard,
make him beleeue thou art ſir Topas the Curate, doe it
quickly. Ile call ſir Toby the whilſt.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Well, Ile put it on, and I will diſſemble my ſelfe
in’t, and I would I were the firſt that euer diſſembled in
ſuch a gowne. I am not tall enough to become the
funion well, nor leane enough to bee thought a good
Studient: but to be ſaid an honeſt man and a good houſ —
keeper goes as fairely, as to ſay, a carefull man, & a great
ſcholler. The Competitors enter.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Ioue bleſſe thee M. Parſon.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Bonos dies ſir Toby: for as the old hermit of Prage
that neuer ſaw pen and inke, very wittily ſayd to a Neece
of King Gorbodacke, that that is, is: ſo I being M. Parſon,
am M. Parſon; for what is that, but that? and is, but is?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: To him ſir Topas.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: What hoa, I ſay, Peace in this priſon.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: The knaue counterfets well: a good knaue.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Who cals there?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir Topas the Curate, who comes to viſit Maluo-
lio the Lunaticke.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir Topas, ſir Topas, good ſir Topas goe to my
Ladie.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Out hyperbolicall fiend, how vexeſt thou this
man? Talkeſt thou nothing but of Ladies?

speech.speaker: Tob.
speech.line: Well ſaid M. Parſon.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir Topas, neuer was man thus wronged, good
ſir Topas do not thinke I am mad: they haue layde mee
heere in hideous darkneſſe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Fye, thou diſhoneſt ſathan: I call thee by the
moſt modeſt termes, for I am one of thoſe gentle ones,
that will vſe the diuell himſelfe with curteſie: ſayſt thou
that houſe is darke?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: As hell ſir Topas.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why it hath bay Windowes tranſparant as bari —
cadoes, and the cleere ſtores toward the South north, are
as luſtrous as Ebony: and yet complaineſt thou of ob —
ſtruion?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I am not mad ſir Topas, I ſay to you this houſe is
darke.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Madman thou erreſt: I ſay there is no darkneſſe
but ignorance, in which thou art more puzel’d then the
Ægyptians in their fogge.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I ſay this houſe is as darke as Ignorance, thogh
Ignorance were as darke as hell; and I ſay there was ne —
uer man thus abus’d, I am no more madde then you are,
make the triall of it in any conſtant queſtion.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning
Wilde-fowle?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: That the ſoule of our grandam, might happily
inhabite a bird.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What thinkſt thou of his opinion?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I thinke nobly of the ſoule, and no way aproue
his opinion.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Fare thee well: remaine thou ſtill in darkeneſſe,
thou ſhalt hold th’ opinion of Pythagoras, ere I will allow
of thy wits, and feare to kill a Woodcocke, leſt thou diſ —
poſſeſſe the ſoule of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir Topas, ſir Topas.

speech.speaker: Tob.
speech.line: My moſt exquiſite ſir Topas.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Nay I am for all waters.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thou mightſt haue done this without thy berd
and gowne, he ſees thee not.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: To him in thine owne voyce, and bring me word
how thou findſt him: I would we were well ridde of this
knauery. If he may bee conueniently deliuer’d, I would
he were, for I am now ſo farre in offence with my Niece,
that I cannot purſue with any ſafety this ſport the vppe —
ſhot. Come by and by to my Chamber.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Hey Robin, iolly Robin, tell me how thy Lady
does.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Foole.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: My Lady is vnkind, perdie.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Foole.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alas why is ſhe ſo?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Foole, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: She loues another. Who calles, ha?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Good foole, as euer thou wilt deſerue well at
my hand, helpe me to a Candle, and pen, inke, and paper:
as I am a Gentleman, I will liue to bee thankefull to thee
for’t.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: M. Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: I good Foole.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alas ſir, how fell you beſides your fiue witts?

speech.speaker: Mall.
speech.line: Foole, there was neuer man ſo notoriouſlie a —
bus’d: I am as well in my wits (foole) as thou art.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: But as well: then you are mad indeede, if you be
no better in your wits then a foole.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: They haue heere propertied me: keepe mee in
darkeneſſe, ſend Miniſters to me, Aſſes, and doe all they
can to face me out of my wits.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Aduiſe you what you ſay: the Miniſter is heere.
Maluolio, Maluolio, thy wittes the heauens reſtore: en —
deauour thy ſelfe to ſleepe, and leaue thy vaine bibble
babble.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Sir Topas.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Maintaine no words with him good fellow.
Who I ſir, not I ſir. God buy you good ſir Topas: Mar —
ry Amen. I will ſir, I will.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Foole, foole, foole I ſay.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alas ſir be patient. What ſay you ſir, I am ſhent
for ſpeaking to you.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Good foole, helpe me to ſome light, and ſome
paper, I tell thee I am as well in my wittes, as any man in
Illyria.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Well-a-day, that you were ſir.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: By this hand I am: good foole, ſome inke, pa —
per, and light: and conuey what I will ſet downe to my
Lady: it ſhall aduantage thee more, then euer the bea —
ring of Letter did.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I will help you too’t. But tel me true, are you not
mad indeed, or do you but counterfeit.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Beleeue me I am not, I tell thee true.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Nay, Ile nere beleeue a madman till I ſee his brains
I will fetch you light, and paper, and inke.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Foole, Ile requite it in the higheſt degree:
I prethee be gone.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I am gone ſir, and anon ſir,
Ile be with you againe:
In a trice, like to the old vice,
your neede to ſuſtaine.
Who with dagger of lath, in his rage and his wrath,
cries ah ha, to the diuell:
Like a mad lad, paire thy nayles dad,
Adieu good man diuell.
This is the ayre, that is the glorious Sunne,
This pearle ſhe gaue me, I do feel’t, and ſee’t,
And though tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet ‘tis not madneſſe. Where’s Anthonio then,
I could not finde him at the Elephant,
Yet there he was, and there I found this credite,
That he did range the towne to ſeeke me out,
His councell now might do me golden ſeruice,
For though my ſoule diſputes well with my ſence,
That this may be ſome error, but no madneſſe,
Yet doth this accident and flood of Fortune,
So farre exceed all inſtance, all diſcourſe,
That I am readie to diſtruſt mine eyes,
And wrangle with my reaſon that perſwades me
To any other truſt, but that I am mad,
Or elſe the Ladies mad; yet if ‘twere ſo,
She could not ſway her houſe, command her followers,
Take, and giue backe affayres, and their diſpatch,
With ſuch a ſmooth, diſcreet, and ſtable bearing
As I perceiue ſhe do’s: there’s ſomething in’t
That is deceiueable. But heere the Lady comes.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Blame not this haſte of mine: if you meane well
Now go with me, and with this holy man
Into the Chantry by: there before him,
And vnderneath that conſecrated roofe,
Plight me the full aſſurance of your faith,
That my moſt iealious, and too doubtfull ſoule
May liue at peace. He ſhall conceale it,
Whiles you are willing it ſhall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keepe
According to my birth, what do you ſay?

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Ile follow this good man, and go with you,
And hauing ſworne truth, euer will be true.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Then lead the way good father, & heauens ſo ſhine,
That they may fairely note this ae of mine.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Now as thou lou’ſt me, let me ſee his Letter.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Good M. Fabian, grant me another requeſt.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Any thing.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Do not deſire to ſee this Letter.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: This is to giue a dogge, and in recompence deſire
my dogge againe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, Viola, Curio, and Lords.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Belong you to the Lady Oliuia, friends?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I ſir, we are ſome of her trappings.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I know thee well: how doeſt thou my good
Fellow?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Truely ſir, the better for my foes, and the worſe
for my friends.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Iuſt the contrary: the better for thy friends.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No ſir, the worſe.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: How can that be?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Marry ſir, they praiſe me, and make an aſſe of me,
now my foes tell me plainly, I am an Aſſe: ſo that by my
foes ſir, I profit in the knowledge of my ſelfe, and by my
friends I am abuſed: ſo that concluſions to be as kiſſes, if
your foure negatiues make your two affirmatiues, why
then the worſe for my friends, and the better for my foes.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why this is excellent.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: By my troth ſir, no: though it pleaſe you to be
one of my friends.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not be the worſe for me, there’s gold.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: But that it would be double dealing ſir, I would
you could make it another.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O you giue me ill counſell.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Put your grace in your pocket ſir, for this once,
and let your fleſh and blood obey it.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Well, I will be ſo much a ſinner to be a double
dealer: there’s another.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Primo, ſecundo, tertio, is a good play, and the olde
ſaying is, the third payes for all: the triplex ſir, is a good
tripping meaſure, or the belles of S. Bennet ſir, may put
you in minde, one, two, three.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: You can foole no more money out of mee at this
throw: if you will let your Lady know I am here to ſpeak
with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my
bounty further.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Marry ſir, lullaby to your bountie till I come a —
gen. I go ſir, but I would not haue you to thinke, that
my deſire of hauing is the ſinne of couetouſneſſe: but as
you ſay ſir, let your bounty take a nappe, I will awake it
anon.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Here comes the man ſir, that did reſcue mee.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: That face of his I do remember well,
Yet when I ſaw it laſt, it was beſmear’d
As blacke as Vulcan, in the ſmoake of warre:
A bawbling Veſſell was he Captaine of,
For ſhallow draught and bulke vnprizable,
With which ſuch ſcathfull grapple did he make,
With the moſt noble bottome of our Fleete,
That very enuy, and the tongue of loſſe
Cride fame and honor on him: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: 1.Offi.
speech.line: Orſino, this is that Anthonio
That tooke the Phœnix, and her fraught from Candy,
And this is he that did the Tiger boord,
When your yong Nephew Titus loſt his legge;
Heere in the ſtreets, deſperate of ſhame and ſtate,
In priuate brabble did we apprehend him.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: He did me kindneſſe ſir, drew on my ſide,
But in concluſion put ſtrange ſpeech vpon me,
I know not what ‘twas, but diſtraion.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Notable Pyrate, thou ſalt-water Theefe,
What fooliſh boldneſſe brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou in termes ſo bloudie, and ſo deere
Haſt made thine enemies?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Orſino: Noble ſir,
Be pleas’d that I ſhake off theſe names you giue mee:
Anthonio neuer yet was Theefe, or Pyrate,
Though I confeſſe, on baſe and ground enough
Orſino’s enemie. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That moſt ingratefull boy there by your ſide,
From the rude ſeas enrag’d and foamy mouth
Did I redeeme: a wracke paſt hope he was:
His life I gaue him, and did thereto adde
My loue without retention, or reſtraint,
All his in dedication. For his ſake,
Did I expoſe my ſelfe (pure for his loue)
Into the danger of this aduerſe Towne,
Drew to defend him, when he was beſet:
Where being apprehended, his falſe cunning
(Not meaning to partake with me in danger)
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twentie yeeres remoued thing
While one would winke: denide me mine owne purſe,
Which I had recommended to his vſe,
Not halfe an houre before.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: How can this be?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: When came he to this Towne?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To day my Lord: and for three months before,
No intrim, not a minutes vacancie,
Both day and night did we keepe companie.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Heere comes the Counteſſe, now heauen walkes
on earth:
But for thee fellow, fellow thy words are madneſſe,
Three monthes this youth hath tended vpon mee,
But more of that anon. Take him aſide.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What would my Lord, but that he may not haue,
Wherein Oliuia may ſeeme ſeruiceable?
Ceſario, you do not keepe promiſe with me.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Madam:

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Gracious Oliuia.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What do you ſay Ceſario? Good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My Lord would ſpeake, my dutie huſhes me.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: If it be ought to the old tune my Lord,
It is as fat and fulſome to mine eare
As howling after Muſicke.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Still ſo cruell?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Still ſo conſtant Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: What to peruerſeneſſe? you vnciuill Ladie
To whoſe ingrate, and vnauſpicious Altars
My ſoule the faithfull’ſt offrings haue breath’d out
That ere deuotion tender’d. What ſhall I do?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Euen what it pleaſe my Lord, that ſhal becom him

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why ſhould I not, (had I the heart to do it)
Like to th’ Egyptian theefe, at point of death
Kill what I loue: (a ſauage iealouſie,
That ſometime ſauours nobly) but heare me this:
Since you to non-regardance caſt my faith,
And that I partly know the inſtrument
That ſcrewes me from my true place in your fauour:
Liue you the Marble-breſted Tirant ſtill.
But this your Minion, whom I know you loue,
And whom, by heauen I ſweare, I tender deerely,
Him will I teare out of that cruell eye,
Where he ſits crowned in his maſters ſpight.
Come boy with me, my thoughts are ripe in miſchiefe:
Ile ſacrifice the Lambe that I do loue,
To ſpight a Rauens heart within a Doue.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And I moſt iocund, apt, and willinglie,
To do you reſt, a thouſand deaths would dye.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Where goes Ceſario?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: After him I loue,
More then I loue theſe eyes, more then my life,
More by all mores, then ere I ſhall loue wife.
If I do feigne, you witneſſes aboue
Puniſh my life, for tainting of my loue.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Aye me deteſted, how am I beguil’d?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Haſt thou forgot thy ſelfe? Is it ſo long?
Call forth the holy Father.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Come, away.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Whether my Lord? Ceſario, Husband, ſtay.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Husband?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I Husband. Can he that deny?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Her husband, ſirrah?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: No my Lord, not I.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Alas, it is the baſeneſſe of thy feare,
That makes thee ſtrangle thy propriety:
Feare not Ceſario, take thy fortunes vp,
Be that thou know’ſt thou art, and then thou art
As great as that thou fear’ſt.
O welcome Father:
Father, I charge thee by thy reuerence
Heere to vnfold, though lately we intended
To keepe in darkeneſſe, what occaſion now
Reueales before ‘tis ripe: what thou doſt know
Hath newly paſt, betweene this youth, and me.

speech.speaker: Prieſt.
speech.line: A Contra of eternall bond of loue,
Confirm’d by mutuall ioynder of your hands,
Atteſted by the holy cloſe of lippes,
Strengthned by enterchangement of your rings,
And all the Ceremonie of this compa
Seal’d in my funion, by my teſtimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my graue
I haue trauail’d but two houres.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: O thou diſſembling Cub: what wilt thou be
When time hath ſow’d a grizzle on thy caſe?
Or will not elſe thy craft ſo quickely grow,
That thine owne trip ſhall be thine ouerthrow:
Farewell, and take her, but dire thy feete,
Where thou, and I (henceforth) may neuer meet.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My Lord, I do proteſt.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: O do not ſweare,
Hold little faith, though thou haſt too much feare.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: For the loue of God a Surgeon, ſend one pre —
ſently to ſir Toby.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: H’as broke my head a-croſſe, and has giuen Sir
Toby a bloody Coxcombe too: for the loue of God your
helpe, I had rather then forty pound I were at home.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Who has done this ſir Andrew?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: The Counts Gentleman, one Ceſario: we tooke
him for a Coward, but hee’s the verie diuell, incardinate.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: My Gentleman Ceſario?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Odd’s lifelings heere he is: you broke my head
for nothing, and that that I did, I was ſet on to do’t by ſir
Toby.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Why do you ſpeake to me, I neuer hurt you:
you drew your ſword vpon me without cauſe,
But I beſpake you faire, and hurt you not.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: If a bloody coxcombe be a hurt, you haue hurt
me: I thinke you ſet nothing by a bloody Coxecombe.
Heere comes ſir Toby halting, you ſhall heare more: but if
he had not beene in drinke, hee would haue tickel’d you
other gates then he did.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: How now Gentleman? how iſt with you?

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: That’s all one, has hurt me, and there’s th’ end on’t:
Sot, didſt ſee Dicke Surgeon, ſot?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: O he’s drunke ſir Toby an houre agone: his eyes
were ſet at eight i’th morning.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Then he’s a Rogue, and a paſſy meaſures panyn: I
hate a drunken rogue.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Away with him? Who hath made this hauocke
with them?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Ile helpe you ſir Toby, becauſe we’ll be dreſt to —
gether.

speech.speaker: To.
speech.line: Will you helpe an Aſſe-head, and a coxcombe, &
a knaue: a thin fac’d knaue, a gull?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be look’d too.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: I am ſorry Madam I haue hurt your kinſman:
But had it beene the brother of my blood,
I muſt haue done no leſſe with wit and ſafety.
You throw a ſtrange regard vpon me, and by that
I do perceiue it hath offended you:
Pardon me (ſweet one) euen for the vowes
We made each other, but ſo late ago.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: One face, one voice, one habit, and two perſons,
A naturall Perſpeiue, that is, and is not.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Anthonio: O my deere Anthonio,
How haue the houres rack’d, and tortur’d me,
Since I haue lost thee?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Sebaſtian are you?

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Fear’ſt thou that Anthonio?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: How haue you made diuiſion of your ſelfe,
An apple cleft in two, is not more twin
Then theſe two creatures. Which is Sebaſtian?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Moſt wonderfull.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: Do I ſtand there? I neuer had a brother:
Nor can there be that Deity in my nature
Of heere, and euery where. I had a ſiſter,
Whom the blinde waues and ſurges haue deuour’d:
Of charity, what kinne are you to me?
What Countreyman? What name? What Parentage?

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: Of Meſſaline: Sebaſtian was my Father,
Such a Sebaſtian was my brother too:
So went he ſuited to his watery tombe:
If ſpirits can aſſume both forme and ſuite,
You come to fright vs.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: A ſpirit I am indeed,
But am in that dimenſion groſſely clad,
Which from the wombe I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the reſt goes euen,
I ſhould my teares let fall vpon your cheeke,
And ſay, thrice welcome drowned Viola.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: My father had a moale vpon his brow.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: And ſo had mine.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And dide that day when Viola from her birth
Had numbred thirteene yeares.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: O that record is liuely in my ſoule,
He finiſhed indeed his mortall ae
That day that made my ſiſter thirteene yeares.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: If nothing lets to make vs happie both,
But this my maſculine vsurp’d attyre:
Do not embrace me, till each circumſtance,
Of place, time, fortune, do co-here and iumpe
That I am Viola, which to confirme,
Ile bring you to a Captaine in this Towne,
Where lye my maiden weeds: by whoſe gentle helpe,
I was preſeru’d to ſerue this Noble Count:
All the occurrence of my fortune ſince
Hath beene betweene this Lady, and this Lord.

speech.speaker: Seb.
speech.line: So comes it Lady, you haue beene miſtooke:
But Nature to her bias drew in that.
You would haue bin contraed to a Maid,
Nor are you therein (by my life) deceiu’d,
You are betroth’d both to a maid and man.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Be not amaz’d, right noble is his blood:
If this be ſo, as yet the glaſſe ſeemes true,
I ſhall haue ſhare in this moſt happy wracke,
Boy, thou haſt ſaide to me a thouſand times,
Thou neuer ſhould’ſt loue woman like to me.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: And all thoſe ſayings, will I ouer ſweare,
And all thoſe ſwearings keepe as true in ſoule,
As doth that Orbed Continent, the fire,
That ſeuers day from night.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Giue me thy hand,
And let me ſee thee in thy womans weedes.

speech.speaker: Vio.
speech.line: The Captaine that did bring me firſt on ſhore
Hath my Maides garments: he vpon ſome Aion
Is now in durance, at Maluolio’s ſuite,
A Gentleman, and follower of my Ladies.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: He ſhall inlarge him: fetch Maluolio hither,
And yet alas, now I remember me,
They ſay poore Gentleman, he’s much distra.
speech.stagedir: Enter Clowne with a Letter, and Fabian.
speech.line: A moſt extraing frenſie of mine owne
From my remembrance, clearly baniſht his.
How does he ſirrah?

speech.speaker: Cl.
speech.line: Truely Madam, he holds Belzebub at the ſtaues end as
well as a man in his caſe may do: has heere writ a letter to
you, I ſhould haue giuen’t you to day morning. But as a
madmans Epiſtles are no Goſpels, ſo it ſkilles not much
when they are deliuer’d.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Open’t, and read it.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Looke then to be well edified, when the Foole
deliuers the Madman. By the Lord Madam.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: How now, art thou mad?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No Madam, I do but reade madneſſe: and your
Ladyſhip will haue it as it ought to bee, you muſt allow
Vox.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Prethee reade i’thy right wits.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: So I do Madona: but to reade his right wits, is to
reade thus: therefore, perpend my Princeſſe, and giue
eare.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Read it you, ſirrah.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: By the Lord Madam, you wrong me, and
the world ſhall know it: Though you haue put mee into
darkeneſſe, and giuen your drunken Coſine rule ouer me,
yet haue I the benefit of my ſenſes as well as your Ladie —
ſhip. I haue your owne letter, that induced mee to the
ſemblance I put on; with the which I doubt not, but to
do my ſelfe much right, or you much ſhame: thinke of
me as you pleaſe. I leaue my duty a little vnthought of,
and ſpeake out of my iniury. The madly vs’d Maluolio.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Did he write this?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I Madame.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: This ſauours not much of diſtraion.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: See him deliuer’d Fabian, bring him hither:
My Lord, ſo pleaſe you, theſe things further thought on,
To thinke me as well a ſiſter, as a wife,
One day ſhall crowne th’ alliance on’t, ſo pleaſe you,
Heere at my houſe, and at my proper coſt.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Madam, I am moſt apt t’ embrace your offer:
Your Maſter quits you: and for your ſeruice done him,
So much againſt the mettle of your ſex,
So farre beneath your ſoft and tender breeding,
And ſince you call’d me Maſter, for ſo long:
Heere is my hand, you ſhall from this time bee
Your Maſters Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: A ſiſter, you are ſhe.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Is this the Madman?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: I my Lord, this ſame: How now Maluolio?

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Madam, you haue done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Haue I Maluolio? No.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Lady you haue, pray you peruſe that Letter.
You muſt not now denie it is your hand,
Write from it if you can, in hand, or phraſe,
Or ſay, tis not your ſeale, not your inuention:
You can ſay none of this. Well, grant it then,
And tell me in the modeſtie of honor,
Why you haue giuen me ſuch cleare lights of fauour,
Bad me come ſmiling, and croſſe-garter’d to you,
To put on yellow ſtockings, and to frowne
Vpon ſir Toby, and the lighter people:
And aing this in an obedient hope,
Why haue you ſuffer’d me to be impriſon’d,
Kept in a darke houſe, viſited by the Prieſt,
And made the moſt notorious gecke and gull,
That ere inuention plaid on? Tell me why?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Alas Maluolio, this is not my writing,
Though I confeſſe much like the Charraer:
But out of queſtion, tis Marias hand.
And now I do bethinke me, it was ſhee
Firſt told me thou waſt mad; then cam’ſt in ſmiling,
And in ſuch formes, which heere were preſuppos’d
Vpon thee in the Letter: prethee be content,
This praice hath moſt ſhrewdly paſt vpon thee:
But when we know the grounds, and authors of it,
Thou ſhalt be both the Plaintiffe and the Iudge
Of thine owne cauſe.

speech.speaker: Fab.
speech.line: Good Madam heare me ſpeake,
And let no quarrell, nor no braule to come,
Taint the condition of this preſent houre,
Which I haue wondred at. In hope it ſhall not,
Moſt freely I confeſſe my ſelfe, and Toby
Set this deuice againſt Maluolio heere,
Vpon ſome ſtubborne and vncourteous parts
We had conceiu’d againſt him. Maria writ
The Letter, at ſir Tobyes great importance,
In recompence whereof, he hath married her:
How with a ſportfull malice it was follow’d,
May rather plucke on laughter then reuenge,
If that the iniuries be iuſtly weigh’d,
That haue on both ſides paſt.

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: Alas poore Foole, how haue they baffel’d thee?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why ſome are borne great, ſome atchieue great —
neſſe, and ſome haue greatneſſe throwne vpon them. I
was one ſir, in this Enterlude, one ſir Topas ſir, but that’s
all one: By the Lord Foole, I am not mad: but do you re —
member, Madam, why laugh you at ſuch a barren raſcall,
and you ſmile not he’s gag’d: and thus the whirlegigge
of time, brings in his reuenges.

speech.speaker: Mal.
speech.line: Ile be reueng’d on the whole packe of you?

speech.speaker: Ol.
speech.line: He hath bene moſt notoriouſly abus’d.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Purſue him, and entreate him to a peace:
He hath not told vs of the Captaine yet,
When that is knowne, and golden time conuents
A ſolemne Combination ſhall be made
Of our deere ſoules. Meane time ſweet ſiſter,
We will not part from hence. Ceſario come
(For ſo you ſhall be while you are a man:)
But when in other habites you are ſeene,
Orſino’s Miſtris, and his fancies Queene.

stanza.line: When that I was and a little tine boy,
with hey, ho, the winde and the raine:
A foolish thing was but a toy,
for the raine it raineth euery day.
But when I came to mans eſtate,
with hey ho, &c.
Gainſt Knaues and Theeues men ſhut their gate,
for the raine, &c.
But when I came alas to wiue,
with hey ho, &c.
By ſwaggering could I neuer thriue,
for the raine, &c.
But when I came vnto my beds,
with hey ho, &c.
With toſpottes ſtill had drunken heades,
for the raine, &c.
A great while ago the world begon,
hey ho, &c.
But that’s all one, our Play is done,
and wee’l ſtriue to pleaſe you euery day.
